"loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Russia"}, "location": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "Russia"}}}], "eventDate": "2024-07-23", "totalArticleCount": 248, "title": {"eng": "Hamas and Fatah sign agreement in Beijing 'ending' their division, Chinese state media says"}, "summary": {"eng": "Palestinian factions including rivals Hamas and Fatah have signed an agreement on \"ending division and strengthening Palestinian unity,\" Chinese broadcaster CCTV said Tuesday, following a deal brokered by China.\n\nThe announcement followed reconciliation talks involving 14 Palestinian factions in Beijing starting Sunday, according to state media, which come as Israel wages war against militant group Hamas in Gaza and as China has sought to take up a role as a peace broker in the conflict.\n\nChinese"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Beijing"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "China"}}}, "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Warfare_and_Conflict", "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Warfare and Conflict", "wgt": 81}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Politics/Nationalism", "label": "dmoz/Society/Politics/Nationalism", "wgt": 82}, {"uri": "news/Politics", "label": "news/Politics", "wgt": 88}], "articleCounts": {"eng": 248}, "sentiment": 0.0117647058823529, "breakingScore": 0.8000186604491598}
{"uri": "8239518825", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-23", "time": "13:42:54", "dateTime": "2024-07-23T13:42:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-23T13:35:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8627451062202454, "url": "https://www.eagletribune.com/region/rivals-hamas-and-fatah-sign-a-declaration-to-form-a-future-government-as-war-rages/article_7f1dc4fc-c7c5-51d8-879f-a893201c8ac1.html", "title": "Rivals Hamas and Fatah sign a declaration to form a future government as war rages in Gaza", "body": "Mussa Abu Marzuk of Hamas speaks during an event for him and Mahmoud al-Aloul of Fatah to meet, as it was hosted by China's Foreign Minister Wang Yi, at the Diaoyutai State Guesthouse in Beijing, Tuesday, July 23, 2024.\n\nRAMALLAH, West Bank (AP) -- Palestinian factions Hamas and Fatah signed a declaration in Beijing vowing to form a government together, the groups said Tuesday, in the latest attempt at resolving their long rivalry.\n\nBoth sides said the accord, which provided no guarantees or timeline, was only an initial step. Previous such declarations have failed, raising doubt over whether the China-sponsored negotiations might lead to a resolution between Hamas, which has ruled the Gaza Strip for the past 17 years, and Fatah, the main force in the U.S.-backed Palestinian Authority that administers parts of the occupied West Bank.\n\nIsrael swiftly denounced the agreement. The U.S. and other Western countries have refused to accept any Palestinian government that includes Hamas unless it expressly recognizes Israel -- a factor that has helped wreck past unity attempts, along with the factions' own competition for power.\n\nChinese state broadcaster CCTV announced that the two sides and other, smaller Palestinian factions signed the Beijing Declaration on \"ending division and strengthening Palestinian unity,\" pledging to form a unity government for the Palestinian territories. The agreement offered only broad outlines on how they would work together.\n\n\"There is an opportunity ... but it is not big, because it lacks a specific timetable for implementation,\" said Hani Al-Masry, an expert on Palestinian reconciliation affairs.\n\nThe declaration comes at a sensitive time, as the war in Gaza rages on into its 10th month and as Israel and Hamas are weighing an internationally backed cease-fire proposal that would wind down the war and free dozens of Israeli hostages held by Hamas.\n\nOne of the thorniest issues is the question of who will run Gaza after the war -- and the unity efforts are in part motivated by Palestinians' desire to offer a scenario for postwar rule.\n\nBut Israel vehemently opposes any role for Hamas, which it has vowed to destroy after its Oct. 7 attack on southern Israel. It also has rejected U.S. calls for the Palestinian Authority to govern Gaza after the fighting ends, though it has not presented a cohesive postwar vision of its own.\n\nPalestinian President Mahmoud Abbas' Fatah has been deeply reluctant to share power with its longtime rival. Hamas won Palestinian parliamentary elections in 2006. The following year, amid escalating tensions, Hamas routed forces loyal to Abbas in Gaza. It has ruled the impoverished coastal enclave ever since.\n\nDuring the current war, Hamas officials have said the group does not want to return to ruling Gaza and advocates forming a government of technocrats to be agreed upon by the various Palestinian factions. That government would then prepare for elections in Gaza and the West Bank, with the intention of forming a unified government.\n\nReacting to the announcement out of China, Israel's foreign minister said no joint governance between Hamas and Fatah in Gaza will take place \"because Hamas' rule will be crushed.\"\n\nThe agreement also underscored China's attempts to have a growing role in Middle East diplomacy, after its success in mediating the restoration of relations between Saudi Arabia and Iran.\n\n\"To be sure, China is still in the process of trying to earn credibility as a global mediator,\" said James Char, a research fellow at the Institute of Defence and Strategic Studies at Nanyang Technological University in Singapore.\n\nOfficials from Fatah, Hamas and 12 other factions met with Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi, concluding talks that started Sunday, according to a post on social media platform Weibo from Chinese TV network CGTN.\n\nThe Palestinian factions issued a joint statement announcing the deal but giving no details on how or when the government would be formed, saying only that it would be done \"by agreement among the factions.\" It said they promised to follow up on previous reconciliation agreements signed in 2011 and 2022.\n\nIn the statement, all the factions including Hamas said they were committed to the creation of a Palestinian state on lands Israel captured in the 1967 Mideast war.\n\nHamas, whose original charter directly called for Israel's destruction, has said it would accept a Palestinian state based on the pre-1967 war borders but refuses to officially recognize Israel.\n\nThe Palestinian Authority, meanwhile, has recognized Israel and works within the framework of peace deals signed in the early 1990s. Those deals were supposed to lead to an eventual state in the West Bank and Gaza, but talks have been defunct for years, leaving it in charge of only isolated West Bank enclaves. Many Palestinians view the authority as corrupt, out of touch and a subcontractor for Israel because of their joint security coordination.\n\nThe unity announcement is based on widening the membership of the Fatah-led Palestine Liberation Organization, including Hamas, said Jamal Nazzal, a Fatah spokesperson.\n\n\"It's a long way ahead, and most of it will be implemented after a possible cease-fire,\" he added.\n\nHamas members have never been part of the PLO, the umbrella group of Palestinian factions that undergirds the Palestinian Authority. Husam Badran, a Hamas political official based in Qatar, called the agreement a further \"positive step towards achieving Palestinian national unity.\"\n\nU.S. President Joe Biden's administration envisions a revamped Palestinian Authority ruling postwar Gaza and has sought reforms that might make it a viable presence in the war-ravaged territory. Israel rejected that idea.\n\nThe Palestinian Islamic Jihad, a smaller militant group allied with Hamas, issued a statement after the talks saying it still \"rejects any formula that includes recognition of Israel explicitly or implicitly\" and that it had \"demanded the withdrawal of the Palestine Liberation Organization's recognition of Israel.\"\n\nGoldenberg reported from Tel Aviv, Israel; Wu reported from Bangkok. Abby Sewell contributed to this report from Beirut.", "source": {"uri": "eagletribune.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Eagle-Tribune"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@eagletribune.com", {"uri": "8239651977", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-23", "time": "14:56:17", "dateTime": "2024-07-23T14:56:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-23T14:55:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8509804010391235, "url": "https://www.news18.com/world/rival-palestinian-groups-hamas-fatah-sign-deal-in-china-to-form-unity-govt-8976055.html", "title": "Rival Palestinian Groups Hamas, Fatah Sign Deal In China To Form Unity Govt - News18", "body": "The Beijing Declaration saw the parties take the initial step to form a unity government for the Palestinian territories.\n\nPalestinian factions Hamas and Fatah signed a declaration in Beijing vowing to form a government together, the groups said Tuesday, in the latest attempt at resolving their long rivalry.\n\nBoth sides said the accord, which provided no guarantees or timeline, was only an initial step. Previous such declarations have failed, raising doubt over whether the China-sponsored negotiations might lead to a resolution between Hamas, which has ruled the Gaza Strip for the past 17 years, and Fatah, the main force in the U.S.-backed Palestinian Authority that administers parts of the occupied West Bank.\n\nIsrael swiftly denounced the agreement. The agreement offered only broad outlines on how they would work together.\n\n\"There is an opportunity ... but it is not big, because it lacks a specific timetable for implementation,\" said Hani Al-Masry, an expert on Palestinian reconciliation affairs.\n\nThe declaration comes at a sensitive time, as the war in Gaza rages on into its 10th month and as Israel and Hamas are weighing an internationally backed cease-fire proposal that would wind down the war and free dozens of Israeli hostages held by Hamas.\n\nOne of the thorniest issues is the question of who will run Gaza after the war -- and the unity efforts are in part motivated by Palestinians' desire to offer a scenario for postwar rule.\n\nBut Israel vehemently opposes any role for Hamas, which it has vowed to destroy after its Oct. 7 attack on southern Israel. Hamas won Palestinian parliamentary elections in 2006. The following year, amid escalating tensions, Hamas routed forces loyal to Abbas in Gaza. It has ruled the impoverished coastal enclave ever since.\n\nDuring the current war, Hamas officials have said the group does not want to return to ruling Gaza and advocates forming a government of technocrats to be agreed upon by the various Palestinian factions. That government would then prepare for elections in Gaza and the West Bank, with the intention of forming a unified government.\n\nReacting to the announcement out of China, Israel's foreign minister said no joint governance between Hamas and Fatah in Gaza will take place \"because Hamas' rule will be crushed.\"\n\nThe agreement also underscored China's attempts to have a growing role in Middle East diplomacy, after its success in mediating the restoration of relations between Saudi Arabia and Iran.\n\n\"To be sure, China is still in the process of trying to earn credibility as a global mediator,\" said James Char, a research fellow at the Institute of Defence and Strategic Studies at Nanyang Technological University in Singapore.\n\nOfficials from Fatah, Hamas and 12 other factions met with Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi, concluding talks that started Sunday, according to a post on social media platform Weibo from Chinese TV network CGTN.\n\nThe Palestinian factions issued a joint statement announcing the deal but giving no details on how or when the government would be formed, saying only that it would be done \"by agreement among the factions.\" It said they promised to follow up on previous reconciliation agreements signed in 2011 and 2022.\n\nIn the statement, all the factions including Hamas said they were committed to the creation of a Palestinian state on lands Israel captured in the 1967 Mideast war.\n\nHamas, whose original charter directly called for Israel's destruction, has said it would accept a Palestinian state based on the pre-1967 war borders but refuses to officially recognize Israel.\n\nThe Palestinian Authority, meanwhile, has recognized Israel and works within the framework of peace deals signed in the early 1990s. Those deals were supposed to lead to an eventual state in the West Bank and Gaza, but talks have been defunct for years, leaving it in charge of only isolated West Bank enclaves. Many Palestinians view the authority as corrupt, out of touch and a subcontractor for Israel because of their joint security coordination.\n\nThe unity announcement is based on widening the membership of the Fatah-led Palestine Liberation Organization, including Hamas, said Jamal Nazzal, a Fatah spokesperson.\n\n\"It's a long way ahead, and most of it will be implemented after a possible cease-fire,\" he added.\n\nHamas members have never been part of the PLO, the umbrella group of Palestinian factions that undergirds the Palestinian Authority. Husam Badran, a Hamas political official based in Qatar, called the agreement a further \"positive step towards achieving Palestinian national unity.\"\n\nUS President Joe Biden's administration envisions a revamped Palestinian Authority ruling postwar Gaza and has sought reforms that might make it a viable presence in the war-ravaged territory. Israel rejected that idea.\n\nThe Palestinian Islamic Jihad, a smaller militant group allied with Hamas, issued a statement after the talks saying it still \"rejects any formula that includes recognition of Israel explicitly or implicitly\" and that it had \"demanded the withdrawal of the Palestine Liberation Organization's recognition of Israel.\"", "source": {"uri": "news18.com", {"uri": "2024-07-430764806", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-23", "time": "10:52:59", "dateTime": "2024-07-23T10:52:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-23T05:34:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2024/jul/23/fatah-hamas-sign-declaration-in-beijing-on-ending-/", "title": "Hamas and Fatah sign declaration in Beijing on ending yearslong rift as war rages in Gaza", "body": "RAMALLAH, West Bank (AP) -- Palestinian factions Hamas and Fatah signed a declaration in Beijing on ending a yearslong rift, Chinese state media said Tuesday, taking a step toward potentially resolving the deep divide between the sides as the war in Gaza rages on.\n\nThe declaration by the two heavyweights of Palestinian politics -- and other smaller Palestinian groups -- to form a unity government for the Palestinian territories is the result of the latest in a series of talks meant to unite the sides.\n\nBut previous declarations have failed, including a similar deal in 2011, casting doubt over whether the China-sponsored negotiations might actually lead to a resolution. It also comes as Israel and Hamas are weighing an internationally backed cease-fire proposal that would wind down the nine-month war and free dozens of Israeli hostages held by Hamas.\n\nStill, the future of Gaza is undecided, with Israel vehemently opposed to any role by Hamas in governing Gaza. It has also rejected calls from the United States for the Fatah-dominated Palestinian Authority to run Gaza after the war ends. The lack of a postwar vision for running the Gaza Strip has complicated negotiations over a cease-fire.\n\nSince the current war broke out in Gaza almost 10 months ago, Hamas officials have said that the party does not want to return to ruling Gaza as it did before the conflict, and the group has called for formation of a government of technocrats to be agreed upon by the various Palestinian factions, which would prepare the way for elections for both Gaza and the West Bank, with the intention of forming a unified government.\n\nThe two groups signed the Beijing Declaration on \"ending division and strengthening Palestinian unity,\" according to state broadcaster CCTV.\n\nIsrael's Foreign Minister, Israel Katz, swiftly rejected the agreement Tuesday, stating that no joint governance between Hamas and Fatah in Gaza will take place \"because Hamas's rule will be crushed.\"\n\nThe two rival Palestinian groups, along with 12 other political factions, met with Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi, concluding talks that started Sunday, according to a post on social media platform Weibo from Chinese TV network CGTN.\n\nThe agreement also underscores China's growing role in Middle East diplomacy, with success in the restoration of relations between Saudi Arabia and Iran.\n\n\"But to be sure, China is still the process of trying to earn credibility as a global mediator,\" said James Char, a research fellow at the Institute of Defence and Strategic Studies at Nanyang Technological University in Singapore.\n\nA joint statement issued after the most recent talks in Beijing gave no details on how or when the government would be formed, saying only that it would be done \"by agreement among the factions.\" According to the joint statement, the two groups are committed to the creation of a Palestinian state on lands Israel captured in the 1967 Mideast war.\n\nThe deal does not appear to bridge the two group's diverging position on Israel. Hamas previously said it would accept a state based on 1967 borders, while also refusing to officially recognize Israel. The Fatah-dominated Palestinian Authority, meanwhile, abides by interim peace agreements with Israel signed in the early 1990s.\n\nThe agreement signed by the Palestinian factions promised to follow up on previous reconciliation agreements signed in both 2011 and 2022.\n\n\"The understanding in China is based on widening the scope of the membership on the PLO (Palestine Liberation Organization) to include other factions who have not joined it\" including Hamas, said Jamal Nazzal, a Fatah spokesperson.\n\n\"It's a long way ahead, and most of it will be implemented after a possible cease-fire,\" he added.\n\nFatah and Hamas have been rivals since Hamas violently routed forces loyal to Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas' Fatah in Gaza in 2007, taking over the impoverished coastal enclave. The Fatah-dominated Palestinian Authority, headed by Abbas, administers parts of the occupied West Bank. It is widely viewed by the Palestinian public as corrupt, out of touch, and a subcontractor for Israel because of their joint security coordination.\n\nHamas members have never been part of PLO, the Palestinian government body responsible for international affairs. In a statement, Husam Badran, a Hamas political official based in Qatar, praised the agreement, describing it as a further \"positive step towards achieving Palestinian national unity.\"\n\nBut Tuesday's deal doesn't have a hard timeline.\n\n\"There is an opportunity ... but it is not big, because it lacks a specific timetable for implementation,\" said Hani Al-Masry, an expert on Palestinian reconciliation affairs.\n\nRepeated attempts at mending the rift have failed, wrecked by the factions' own bitter rivalry over power and the West's refusal to accept any government that includes Hamas unless it expressly recognizes Israel.\n\nUnited States President Joe Biden's administration envisions a revamped Palestinian Authority to rule postwar Gaza and has sought a series of reforms that might make it a viable presence in the war-ravaged territory. Israel rejected that idea, but has not put forward a credible alternative for who will govern Gaza.\n\nThe Palestinian Islamic Jihad, a smaller militant group allied with Hamas, issued a statement Tuesday after the talks saying that it still \"rejects any formula that includes recognition of Israel explicitly or implicitly\" and that it had \"demanded the withdrawal of the Palestine Liberation Organization's recognition of Israel.\"\n\n___", "source": {"uri": "washingtontimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Washington Times"}, "authors": [{"uri": "huizhong_wu@washingtontimes.com", {"uri": "8239135529", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-23", "time": "09:41:58", "dateTime": "2024-07-23T09:41:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-23T09:41:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "url": "https://www.eagletribune.com/region/hamas-and-fatah-sign-declaration-in-beijing-on-ending-yearslong-rift-as-war-rages-in/article_7f1dc4fc-c7c5-51d8-879f-a893201c8ac1.html", "title": "Hamas and Fatah sign declaration in Beijing on ending yearslong rift as war rages in Gaza", "body": "China's Foreign Minister Wang Yi speaks during an event hosting Mahmoud al-Aloul, vice chairman of Fatah, and Mussa Abu Marzuk, a senior member of Hamas, at the Diaoyutai State Guesthouse in Beijing, Tuesday, July 23, 2024.\n\nRAMALLAH, West Bank (AP) -- Palestinian factions Hamas and Fatah signed a declaration in Beijing on ending a yearslong rift, Chinese state media said Tuesday, taking a step toward potentially resolving the deep divide between the sides as the war in Gaza rages on.\n\nThe declaration by the two heavyweights of Palestinian politics -- and other smaller Palestinian groups -- to form a unity government for the Palestinian territories is the result of the latest in a series of talks meant to unite the sides.\n\nBut previous declarations have failed, including a similar deal in 2011, casting doubt over whether the China-sponsored negotiations might actually lead to a resolution. It also comes as Israel and Hamas are weighing an internationally backed cease-fire proposal that would wind down the nine-month war and free dozens of Israeli hostages held by Hamas.\n\nStill, the future of Gaza is undecided, with Israel vehemently opposed to any role by Hamas in governing Gaza. It has also rejected calls from the United States for the Fatah-dominated Palestinian Authority to run Gaza after the war ends. The lack of a postwar vision for running the Gaza Strip has complicated negotiations over a cease-fire.\n\nSince the current war broke out in Gaza almost 10 months ago, Hamas officials have said that the party does not want to return to ruling Gaza as it did before the conflict, and the group has called for formation of a government of technocrats to be agreed upon by the various Palestinian factions, which would prepare the way for elections for both Gaza and the West Bank, with the intention of forming a unified government.\n\nThe two groups signed the Beijing Declaration on \"ending division and strengthening Palestinian unity,\" according to state broadcaster CCTV.\n\nIsrael's Foreign Minister, Israel Katz, swiftly rejected the agreement Tuesday, stating that no joint governance between Hamas and Fatah in Gaza will take place \"because Hamas's rule will be crushed.\"\n\nThe two rival Palestinian groups, along with 12 other political factions, met with Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi, concluding talks that started Sunday, according to a post on social media platform Weibo from Chinese TV network CGTN.\n\nThe agreement also underscores China's growing role in Middle East diplomacy, with success in the restoration of relations between Saudi Arabia and Iran.\n\n\"But to be sure, China is still the process of trying to earn credibility as a global mediator,\" said James Char, a research fellow at the Institute of Defence and Strategic Studies at Nanyang Technological University in Singapore.\n\nA joint statement issued after the most recent talks in Beijing gave no details on how or when the government would be formed, saying only that it would be done \"by agreement among the factions.\" According to the joint statement, the two groups are committed to the creation of a Palestinian state on lands Israel captured in the 1967 Mideast war.\n\nThe deal does not appear to bridge the two group's diverging position on Israel. Hamas previously said it would accept a state based on 1967 borders, while also refusing to officially recognize Israel. The Fatah-dominated Palestinian Authority, meanwhile, abides by interim peace agreements with Israel signed in the early 1990s.\n\nThe agreement signed by the Palestinian factions promised to follow up on previous reconciliation agreements signed in both 2011 and 2022.\n\n\"The understanding in China is based on widening the scope of the membership on the PLO (Palestine Liberation Organization) to include other factions who have not joined it\" including Hamas, said Jamal Nazzal, a Fatah spokesperson.\n\n\"It's a long way ahead, and most of it will be implemented after a possible cease-fire,\" he added.\n\nFatah and Hamas have been rivals since Hamas violently routed forces loyal to Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas' Fatah in Gaza in 2007, taking over the impoverished coastal enclave. The Fatah-dominated Palestinian Authority, headed by Abbas, administers parts of the occupied West Bank. It is widely viewed by the Palestinian public as corrupt, out of touch, and a subcontractor for Israel because of their joint security coordination.\n\nHamas members have never been part of PLO, the Palestinian government body responsible for international affairs. In a statement, Husam Badran, a Hamas political official based in Qatar, praised the agreement, describing it as a further \"positive step towards achieving Palestinian national unity.\"\n\nBut Tuesday's deal doesn't have a hard timeline.\n\n\"There is an opportunity ... but it is not big, because it lacks a specific timetable for implementation,\" said Hani Al-Masry, an expert on Palestinian reconciliation affairs.\n\nRepeated attempts at mending the rift have failed, wrecked by the factions' own bitter rivalry over power and the West's refusal to accept any government that includes Hamas unless it expressly recognizes Israel.\n\nUnited States President Joe Biden's administration envisions a revamped Palestinian Authority to rule postwar Gaza and has sought a series of reforms that might make it a viable presence in the war-ravaged territory. Israel rejected that idea, but has not put forward a credible alternative for who will govern Gaza.\n\nThe Palestinian Islamic Jihad, a smaller militant group allied with Hamas, issued a statement Tuesday after the talks saying that it still \"rejects any formula that includes recognition of Israel explicitly or implicitly\" and that it had \"demanded the withdrawal of the Palestine Liberation Organization's recognition of Israel.\"\n\nGoldenberg reported from Tel Aviv, Israel; Wu reported from Bangkok. {"uri": "8239526453", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-23", "time": "13:41:37", "dateTime": "2024-07-23T13:41:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-23T13:40:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "url": "https://www.yorkpress.co.uk/news/national/24470944.hamas-fatah-sign-declaration-form-future-government-war-rages-gaza/", "title": "Hamas and Fatah sign declaration to form future government as war rages in Gaza", "body": "Palestinian factions Hamas and Fatah have signed a declaration vowing to form a government together.\n\nThe event, hosted by China, is the latest attempt at resolving the years-long rivalry between the two groups.\n\nBoth sides said the accord, which provided no guarantees or timeline, was only an initial step.\n\nPrevious such declarations have failed, raising doubt over whether the China-sponsored negotiations might lead to a resolution between Hamas, which has ruled the Gaza Strip for the past 17 years, and Fatah, the main force in the US-backed Palestinian Authority that administers parts of the occupied West Bank.\n\nIsrael swiftly denounced the agreement while the US and other Western countries have refused to accept any Palestinian government that includes Hamas unless it expressly recognises Israel -- a factor that has helped wreck past unity attempts, along with the factions' own competition for power.\n\nChinese state broadcaster CCTV announced that the two sides and other, smaller Palestinian factions signed the Beijing Declaration on \"ending division and strengthening Palestinian unity\", pledging to form a unity government for the Palestinian territories.\n\nThe agreement offered only broad outlines of how they would work together.\n\n\"There is an opportunity ... but it is not big, because it lacks a specific timetable for implementation,\" said Hani Al-Masry, an expert on Palestinian reconciliation affairs.\n\nThe declaration comes at a sensitive time, as the war in Gaza rages on into its 10th month and as Israel and Hamas are weighing an internationally backed ceasefire proposal that would wind down the war and free dozens of Israeli hostages held by Hamas.\n\nOne of the thorniest issues is the question of who will run Gaza after the war -- and the unity efforts are in part motivated by Palestinians' desire to offer a scenario for post-war rule.\n\nBut Israel vehemently opposes any role for Hamas, which it has vowed to destroy after its October 7 attack on southern Israel.\n\nIt also has rejected US calls for the Palestinian Authority to govern Gaza after the fighting ends, though it has not presented a cohesive post-war vision of its own.\n\nPalestinian President Mahmoud Abbas's Fatah has been deeply reluctant to share power with its long-time rival.\n\nHamas won Palestinian parliamentary elections in 2006. The following year, amid escalating tensions, Hamas routed forces loyal to Abbas in Gaza. It has ruled the impoverished coastal enclave ever since.\n\nDuring the current war, Hamas officials have said the group does not want to return to ruling Gaza and advocates forming a government of technocrats to be agreed upon by the various Palestinian factions.\n\nThat government would then prepare for elections in Gaza and the West Bank, with the intention of forming a unified government.\n\nReacting to the announcement out of China, Israel's foreign minister said no joint governance between Hamas and Fatah in Gaza will take place \"because Hamas' rule will be crushed\".\n\nThe agreement also underscored China's attempts to have a growing role in Middle East diplomacy, after its success in mediating the restoration of relations between Saudi Arabia and Iran.\n\n\"To be sure, China is still in the process of trying to earn credibility as a global mediator,\" said James Char, a research fellow at the Institute of Defence and Strategic Studies at Nanyang Technological University in Singapore.\n\nOfficials from Fatah, Hamas and 12 other factions met with Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi, concluding talks that started Sunday, according to a post on social media platform Weibo from Chinese TV network CGTN.\n\nThe Palestinian factions issued a joint statement announcing the deal but giving no details on how or when the government would be formed, saying only that it would be done \"by agreement among the factions\".\n\nIt said they promised to follow up on previous reconciliation agreements signed in 2011 and 2022.\n\nIn the statement, all the factions, including Hamas, said they were committed to the creation of a Palestinian state on lands Israel captured in the 1967 Mideast war.\n\nHamas, whose original charter directly called for Israel's destruction, has said it would accept a Palestinian state based on the pre-1967 war borders but refuses to officially recognise Israel.\n\nThe Palestinian Authority, meanwhile, has recognised Israel and works within the framework of peace deals signed in the early 1990s.\n\nThose deals were supposed to lead to an eventual state in the West Bank and Gaza, but talks have been defunct for years, leaving it in charge of only isolated West Bank enclaves.\n\nMany Palestinians view the authority as corrupt, out of touch and a subcontractor for Israel because of their joint security co-ordination.\n\nThe unity announcement is based on widening the membership of the Fatah-led Palestine Liberation Organisation (PLO), including Hamas, said Jamal Nazzal, a Fatah spokesperson.\n\n\"It's a long way ahead, and most of it will be implemented after a possible ceasefire,\" he added.\n\nHamas members have never been part of the PLO, the umbrella group of Palestinian factions that undergirds the Palestinian Authority.\n\nHusam Badran, a Hamas political official based in Qatar, called the agreement a further \"positive step towards achieving Palestinian national unity\".\n\nUS President Joe Biden's administration envisions a revamped Palestinian Authority ruling post-war Gaza and has sought reforms that might make it a viable presence in the war-ravaged territory. However, Israel rejected that idea.\n\nThe Palestinian Islamic Jihad, a smaller militant group allied with Hamas, issued a statement after the talks saying it still \"rejects any formula that includes recognition of Israel explicitly or implicitly\" and that it had \"demanded the withdrawal of the Palestine Liberation Organisation's recognition of Israel\".", "source": {"uri": "yorkpress.co.uk", {"uri": "2024-07-430788230", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-23", "time": "11:11:36", "dateTime": "2024-07-23T11:11:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-23T11:09:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://eu.detroitnews.com/story/news/world/2024/07/23/hamas-fatah-sign-declaration-in-beijing-on-ending-yearslong-rift-as-war-rages-in-gaza/74508483007/", "title": "Hamas and Fatah sign declaration in Beijing on ending yearslong rift as war rages in Gaza", "body": "Ramallah, West Bank -- Palestinian factions Hamas and Fatah signed a declaration in Beijing on ending a yearslong rift, the groups said Tuesday, taking a step toward resolving a deep divide which has lingered for years despite repeated attempts at unifying the sides.\n\nThe two heavyweights of Palestinian politics signed the Beijing Declaration on \"ending division and strengthening Palestinian unity,\" according to Chinese state broadcaster CCTV, pledging to form a unity government for the Palestinian territories. But previous such declarations have failed, including a similar deal in 2011, casting doubt over whether the China-sponsored negotiations might actually lead to a resolution.\n\nThe declaration comes at a sensitive time, as the war in Gaza rages on into its 10th month and as Israel and Hamas are weighing an internationally backed cease-fire proposal that would wind down the war and free dozens of Israeli hostages held by Hamas.\n\nThe question of Palestinian political unity could complicate planning for a postwar leadership structure for Gaza, one of the thornier issues in the ongoing peace talks. Hamas won parliamentary elections in Gaza in 2006 and then overran the territory in a violent takeover the following year.\n\nGaza's postwar future remains in doubt. Israel vehemently opposes any Hamas role in governing Gaza after the war. It has also rejected calls from the United States for the Fatah-dominated Palestinian Authority to run Gaza after the fighting ends.\n\nSince the current war broke out in Gaza almost 10 months ago, Hamas officials have said that the party does not want to return to ruling Gaza as it did before the conflict, and the group has called for formation of a government of technocrats to be agreed upon by the various Palestinian factions, which would prepare the way for elections for both Gaza and the West Bank, with the intention of forming a unified government.\n\nBut both Israel and the PA have deep distrusts about Hamas' intentions.\n\nIsrael's Foreign Minister, Israel Katz, swiftly rejected the agreement Tuesday, stating that no joint governance between Hamas and Fatah in Gaza will take place \"because Hamas's rule will be crushed.\"\n\nThe two rival Palestinian groups, along with 12 other political factions, met with Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi, concluding talks that started Sunday, according to a post on social media platform Weibo from Chinese TV network CGTN.\n\nThe agreement also underscores China's growing role in Middle East diplomacy, with success in the restoration of relations between Saudi Arabia and Iran.\n\n\"But to be sure, China is still the process of trying to earn credibility as a global mediator,\" said James Char, a research fellow at the Institute of Defence and Strategic Studies at Nanyang Technological University in Singapore.\n\nA joint statement issued after the most recent talks in Beijing gave no details on how or when the government would be formed, saying only that it would be done \"by agreement among the factions.\" According to the joint statement, the two groups are committed to the creation of a Palestinian state on lands Israel captured in the 1967 Mideast war.\n\nThe deal does not appear to bridge the two group's diverging position on Israel. Hamas previously said it would accept a state based on the pre-1967 war borders, while also refusing to officially recognize Israel. The Fatah-dominated Palestinian Authority, meanwhile, abides by interim peace agreements with Israel signed in the early 1990s.\n\nThe agreement signed by the Palestinian factions promised to follow up on previous reconciliation agreements signed in both 2011 and 2022.\n\n\"The understanding in China is based on widening the scope of the membership on the PLO (Palestine Liberation Organization) to include other factions who have not joined it\" including Hamas, said Jamal Nazzal, a Fatah spokesperson.\n\n\"It's a long way ahead, and most of it will be implemented after a possible cease-fire,\" he added.\n\nFatah and Hamas have been rivals since Hamas violently routed forces loyal to Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas' Fatah in Gaza in 2007, taking over the impoverished coastal enclave. The Fatah-dominated Palestinian Authority, headed by Abbas, administers parts of the occupied West Bank. It is widely viewed by the Palestinian public as corrupt, out of touch, and a subcontractor for Israel because of their joint security coordination.\n\nHamas members have never been part of PLO, the Palestinian government body responsible for international affairs. In a statement, Husam Badran, a Hamas political official based in Qatar, praised the agreement, describing it as a further \"positive step towards achieving Palestinian national unity.\"\n\nBut Tuesday's deal doesn't have a hard timeline.\n\n\"There is an opportunity ... but it is not big, because it lacks a specific timetable for implementation,\" said Hani Al-Masry, an expert on Palestinian reconciliation affairs.\n\nRepeated attempts at mending the rift have failed, wrecked by the factions' own bitter rivalry over power and the West's refusal to accept any government that includes Hamas unless it expressly recognizes Israel.\n\nUnited States President Joe Biden's administration envisions a revamped Palestinian Authority ruling postwar Gaza and has sought a series of reforms that might make it a viable presence in the war-ravaged territory. Israel rejected that idea, but has not put forward a credible alternative for who will govern Gaza.\n\nThe Palestinian Islamic Jihad, a smaller militant group allied with Hamas, issued a statement Tuesday after the talks saying that it still \"rejects any formula that includes recognition of Israel explicitly or implicitly\" and that it had \"demanded the withdrawal of the Palestine Liberation {"uri": "2024-07-430925973", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-23", "time": "13:11:01", "dateTime": "2024-07-23T13:11:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-23T12:59:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://www.channel3000.com/news/national-and-world-news/israel-conflict/rivals-hamas-and-fatah-sign-a-declaration-to-form-a-future-government-as-war-rages/article_7f840ad2-0228-5726-bf7d-6cd53d27e235.html", "title": "Rivals Hamas and Fatah sign a declaration to form a future government as war rages in Gaza", "body": "By JACK JEFFERY, TIA GOLDENBERG and HUIZHONG WU - Associated Press\n\nRAMALLAH, West Bank (AP) -- Palestinian factions Hamas and Fatah signed a declaration in Beijing vowing to form a government together, the groups said Tuesday, in the latest attempt at resolving their long rivalry.\n\nBoth sides said the accord, which provided no guarantees or timeline, was only an initial step. Previous such declarations have failed, raising doubt over whether the China-sponsored negotiations might lead to a resolution between Hamas, which has ruled the Gaza Strip for the past 17 years, and Fatah, the main force in the U.S.-backed Palestinian Authority that administers parts of the occupied West Bank.\n\nIsrael swiftly denounced the agreement. The U.S. and other Western countries have refused to accept any Palestinian government that includes Hamas unless it expressly recognizes Israel -- a factor that has helped wreck past unity attempts, along with the factions' own competition for power.\n\nChinese state broadcaster CCTV announced that the two sides and other, smaller Palestinian factions signed the Beijing Declaration on \"ending division and strengthening Palestinian unity,\" pledging to form a unity government for the Palestinian territories. The agreement offered only broad outlines on how they would work together.\n\n\"There is an opportunity ... but it is not big, because it lacks a specific timetable for implementation,\" said Hani Al-Masry, an expert on Palestinian reconciliation affairs.\n\nThe declaration comes at a sensitive time, as the war in Gaza rages on into its 10th month and as Israel and Hamas are weighing an internationally backed cease-fire proposal that would wind down the war and free dozens of Israeli hostages held by Hamas.\n\nOne of the thorniest issues is the question of who will run Gaza after the war -- and the unity efforts are in part motivated by Palestinians' desire to offer a scenario for postwar rule.\n\nBut Israel vehemently opposes any role for Hamas, which it has vowed to destroy after its Oct. 7 attack on southern Israel. It also has rejected U.S. calls for the Palestinian Authority to govern Gaza after the fighting ends, though it has not presented a cohesive postwar vision of its own.\n\nPalestinian President Mahmoud Abbas' Fatah has been deeply reluctant to share power with its longtime rival. Hamas won Palestinian parliamentary elections in 2006. The following year, amid escalating tensions, Hamas routed forces loyal to Abbas in Gaza. It has ruled the impoverished coastal enclave ever since.\n\nDuring the current war, Hamas officials have said the group does not want to return to ruling Gaza and advocates forming a government of technocrats to be agreed upon by the various Palestinian factions. That government would then prepare for elections in Gaza and the West Bank, with the intention of forming a unified government.\n\nReacting to the announcement out of China, Israel's foreign minister said no joint governance between Hamas and Fatah in Gaza will take place \"because Hamas' rule will be crushed.\"\n\nThe agreement also underscored China's attempts to have a growing role in Middle East diplomacy, after its success in mediating the restoration of relations between Saudi Arabia and Iran.\n\n\"To be sure, China is still in the process of trying to earn credibility as a global mediator,\" said James Char, a research fellow at the Institute of Defence and Strategic Studies at Nanyang Technological University in Singapore.\n\nOfficials from Fatah, Hamas and 12 other factions met with Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi, concluding talks that started Sunday, according to a post on social media platform Weibo from Chinese TV network CGTN.\n\nThe Palestinian factions issued a joint statement announcing the deal but giving no details on how or when the government would be formed, saying only that it would be done \"by agreement among the factions.\" It said they promised to follow up on previous reconciliation agreements signed in 2011 and 2022.\n\nIn the statement, all the factions including Hamas said they were committed to the creation of a Palestinian state on lands Israel captured in the 1967 Mideast war.\n\nHamas, whose original charter directly called for Israel's destruction, has said it would accept a Palestinian state based on the pre-1967 war borders but refuses to officially recognize Israel.\n\nThe Palestinian Authority, meanwhile, has recognized Israel and works within the framework of peace deals signed in the early 1990s. Those deals were supposed to lead to an eventual state in the West Bank and Gaza, but talks have been defunct for years, leaving it in charge of only isolated West Bank enclaves. Many Palestinians view the authority as corrupt, out of touch and a subcontractor for Israel because of their joint security coordination.\n\nThe unity announcement is based on widening the membership of the Fatah-led Palestine Liberation Organization, including Hamas, said Jamal Nazzal, a Fatah spokesperson.\n\n\"It's a long way ahead, and most of it will be implemented after a possible cease-fire,\" he added.\n\nHamas members have never been part of the PLO, the umbrella group of Palestinian factions that undergirds the Palestinian Authority. Husam Badran, a Hamas political official based in Qatar, called the agreement a further \"positive step towards achieving Palestinian national unity.\"\n\nU.S. President Joe Biden's administration envisions a revamped Palestinian Authority ruling postwar Gaza and has sought reforms that might make it a viable presence in the war-ravaged territory. Israel rejected that idea.\n\nThe Palestinian Islamic Jihad, a smaller militant group allied with Hamas, issued a statement after the talks saying it still \"rejects any formula that includes recognition of Israel explicitly or implicitly\" and that it had \"demanded the withdrawal of the Palestine Liberation Organization's recognition of Israel.\"\n\nGoldenberg reported from Tel Aviv, Israel; Wu reported from Bangkok. Abby Sewell contributed to this report from Beirut.\n\nCOPYRIGHT 2024 BY CHANNEL 3000. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED. {"uri": "2024-07-430964948", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-23", "time": "13:44:42", "dateTime": "2024-07-23T13:44:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-23T13:44:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "http://www.tap.info.tn/en/Portal-World/17709894-palestinian", "title": "Palestinian factions agree to form unity government after talks in China", "body": "BEIJING/CAIRO, July 23 (TAP) - Palestinian factions including rivals Hamas and Fatah agreed to end their divisions and form an interim national unity government during negotiations in China that ended on Tuesday, China's foreign ministry said.\n\nThe Beijing Declaration was signed at the closing ceremony of a reconciliation dialogue among 14 Palestinian factions held in China's capital from July 21-23, according to the readout.\n\nPrevious efforts by Egypt and other Arab countries to reconcile Hamas and Fatah have failed to end 17 years of power-sharing conflict that have weakened Palestinian political aspirations, and it remains to be seen whether this deal will survive the realities on the ground.\n\nThe meeting was held amid attempts by international mediators to reach a ceasefire deal for Gaza, with one of the sticking points being the \"day-after\" plan - how the Hamas-run enclave will be governed once the war that began on Oct. 7 ends.\n\nSenior Hamas official Hussam Badran said the most important point of the Beijing Declaration was to form a Palestinian national unity government to manage the affairs of Palestinians.\n\n\"This creates a formidable barrier against all regional and international interventions that seek to impose realities against our people's interests in managing Palestinian affairs post-war,\" Badran said.\n\nTwo Fatah officials contacted by Reuters declined to comment.\n\nIsraeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has said his goal is to destroy the Iran-backed Hamas group and opposes it having any role in a post war Gaza administration.\n\n\"Instead of rejecting terrorism, (Fatah leader) Mahmoud Abbas embraces the murderers and rapists of Hamas, revealing his true face. In reality, this won't happen because Hamas' rule will be crushed, and Abbas will be watching Gaza from afar. Israel's security will remain solely in Israel's hands,\" Israeli Foreign Minister Israel Katz said on X.\n\nBadran said the national unity government would manage the affairs of Palestinians in Gaza and the West Bank, oversee reconstruction, and prepare conditions for elections.\n\nCurrently Hamas runs Gaza and Fatah forms the backbone of the Palestinian Authority, which has limited control in the Israeli-occupied West Bank.\n\nDetails of the agreement did not set out a timeframe for forming a new government. In March, Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas, who heads Fatah, appointed a new government led by one of his close aides, Mohammad Mustafa.\n\nAshraf Abouelhoul, a specialist on Palestinian affairs, said previous similar declarations had not been implemented and nothing would happened without U.S. approval.\n\n\"Forming a unity government with Hamas is rejected by the United States, Israel, and Britain. There is a consensus among those countries to exclude Hamas from any role in the day after the war,\" Abouelhoul said.\n\n\"What happened in China was nothing but a meeting, a celebratory event, but it is impossible to resolve the problems between Palestinian factions in just three days,\" said Abouelhoul, managing editor of the Egyptian state-owned paper Al-Ahram.\n\nFEUDING FACTIONS\n\nNonetheless, the agreement further demonstrates Beijing's growing influence in the Middle East, after it brokered a breakthrough peace deal between longstanding regional foes Saudi Arabia and Iran last year.\n\n\"The core achievement is to make it clear that the Palestine Liberation Organization is the sole legitimate representative of the Palestinian people,\" Chinese foreign minister Wang Yi said during the closing ceremony, according to the readout.\n\n\"China sincerely hopes that the Palestinian factions will achieve Palestinian independence at an early date on the basis of internal reconciliation, and is willing to strengthen communication and coordination with relevant parties to jointly work to implement the Beijing Declaration reached today.\"\n\nThe most \"prominent highlight\" was the agreement on forming an interim national reconciliation government around the post-war governance of Gaza, Wang said, adding that the international community should support efforts to form an interim Palestinian government to control Gaza and the West Bank.\n\nHamas and Islamic Jihad are not members of the PLO, the Palestinians' highest decision-making body, but they demand that any unity deal includes holding an election for the PLO parliament to secure their inclusion. The Islamist groups are at odds with the current PLO over peace accords with Israel.\n\n\"This declaration comes at an important time as our people are facing a genocidal war, especially in the Gaza Strip,\" a statement quoted Badran as saying.\n\nRival factions Hamas and Fatah first met in Beijing in April to discuss reconciliation efforts to end around 17 years of disputes, the first time a Hamas delegation was publicly known to have visited China since the war in Gaza began.\n\nThe second round of talks, originally planned for last month, were delayed as both factions traded blame.\n\nThe long-feuding Palestinian factions have previously failed to heal their political disputes after Hamas fighters expelled Fatah from Gaza in a short war in 2007.\n\nChinese officials have ramped up advocacy for the Palestinians in international forums in recent months, calling for a larger-scale Israeli-Palestinian peace conference and a specific timetable to implement a two-state {"uri": "8239668102", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-23", "time": "15:06:25", "dateTime": "2024-07-23T15:06:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-23T15:05:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://www.thecitizen.co.tz/tanzania/news/international/palestinian-factions-agree-to-form-unity-government-4699998", "title": "Palestinian factions agree to form unity government", "body": "The Beijing Declaration was signed at the closing ceremony of a reconciliation dialogue among 14 Palestinian factions held in China's capital from July 21-23, according to the readout.\n\nBeijing. Palestinian factions including rivals Hamas and Fatah agreed to end their divisions and form an interim national unity government during negotiations in China that ended on Tuesday, China's foreign ministry said.\n\nThe Beijing Declaration was signed at the closing ceremony of a reconciliation dialogue among 14 Palestinian factions held in China's capital from July 21-23, according to the readout.\n\nPrevious efforts by Egypt and other Arab countries to reconcile Hamas and Fatah have failed to end 17 years of power-sharing conflict that have weakened Palestinian political aspirations, and it remains to be seen whether this deal will survive the realities on the ground.\n\nThe meeting was held amid attempts by international mediators to reach a ceasefire deal for Gaza, with one of the sticking points being the \"day-after\" plan - how the Hamas-run enclave will be governed once the war that began on Oct. 7 ends.\n\nSenior Hamas official Hussam Badran said the most important point of the Beijing Declaration was to form a Palestinian national unity government to manage the affairs of Palestinians.\n\n\"This creates a formidable barrier against all regional and international interventions that seek to impose realities against our people's interests in managing Palestinian affairs post-war,\" Badran said.\n\nTwo Fatah officials contacted by Reuters declined to comment.\n\nIsraeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has said his goal is to destroy the Iran-backed Hamas group and opposes it having any role in a post war Gaza administration.\n\n\"Instead of rejecting terrorism, (Fatah leader) Mahmoud Abbas embraces the murderers and rapists of Hamas, revealing his true face. In reality, this won't happen because Hamas' rule will be crushed, and Abbas will be watching Gaza from afar. Israel's security will remain solely in Israel's hands,\" Israeli Foreign Minister Israel Katz said on X.\n\nBadran said the national unity government would manage the affairs of Palestinians in Gaza and the West Bank, oversee reconstruction, and prepare conditions for elections.\n\nCurrently Hamas runs Gaza and Fatah forms the backbone of the Palestinian Authority, which has limited control in the Israeli-occupied West Bank.\n\nDetails of the agreement did not set out a timeframe for forming a new government. In March, Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas, who heads Fatah, appointed a new government led by one of his close aides, Mohammad Mustafa.\n\nAshraf Abouelhoul, a specialist on Palestinian affairs, said previous similar declarations had not been implemented and nothing would happened without U.S. approval.\n\n\"Forming a unity government with Hamas is rejected by the United States, Israel, and Britain. There is a consensus among those countries to exclude Hamas from any role in the day after the war,\" Abouelhoul said.\n\n\"What happened in China was nothing but a meeting, a celebratory event, but it is impossible to resolve the problems between Palestinian factions in just three days,\" said Abouelhoul, managing editor of the Egyptian state-owned paper Al-Ahram.\n\nFeuding factions\n\nNonetheless, the agreement further demonstrates Beijing's growing influence in the Middle East, after it brokered a breakthrough peace deal between longstanding regional foes Saudi Arabia and Iran last year.\n\n\"The core achievement is to make it clear that the Palestine Liberation Organization is the sole legitimate representative of the Palestinian people,\" Chinese foreign minister Wang Yi said during the closing ceremony, according to the readout.\n\n\"China sincerely hopes that the Palestinian factions will achieve Palestinian independence at an early date on the basis of internal reconciliation, and is willing to strengthen communication and coordination with relevant parties to jointly work to implement the Beijing Declaration reached today.\"\n\nThe most \"prominent highlight\" was the agreement on forming an interim national reconciliation government around the post-war governance of Gaza, Wang said, adding that the international community should support efforts to form an interim Palestinian government to control Gaza and the West Bank.\n\nHamas and Islamic Jihad are not members of the PLO, the Palestinians' highest decision-making body, but they demand that any unity deal includes holding an election for the PLO parliament to secure their inclusion. The Islamist groups are at odds with the current PLO over peace accords with Israel.\n\n\"This declaration comes at an important time as our people are facing a genocidal war, especially in the Gaza Strip,\" a statement quoted Badran as saying.\n\nRival factions Hamas and Fatah first met in Beijing in April to discuss reconciliation efforts to end around 17 years of disputes, the first time a Hamas delegation was publicly known to have visited China since the war in Gaza began.\n\nThe second round of talks, originally planned for last month, were delayed as both factions traded blame.\n\nThe long-feuding Palestinian factions have previously failed to heal their political disputes after Hamas fighters expelled Fatah from Gaza in a short war in 2007.\n\nChinese officials have It also comes as Israel and Hamas are weighing an internationally backed ceasefire proposal that would wind down the nine-month war and free dozens of Israeli hostages held by Hamas.\n\nStill, the future of Gaza is undecided, with Israel vehemently opposed to any role by Hamas in governing Gaza. It has also rejected calls from the United States for the Fatah-dominated Palestinian Authority to run Gaza after the war ends.\n\nThe lack of a post-war vision for running the Gaza Strip has complicated ceasefire negotiations.\n\nSince the current war broke out in Gaza almost 10 months ago, Hamas officials have said that the party does not want to return to ruling Gaza as it did before the conflict.\n\nThe group has called for the formation of a government of technocrats to be agreed upon by the various Palestinian factions, which would prepare the way for elections for both Gaza and the West Bank, with the intention of forming a unified government.\n\nHamas and Fatah signed the Beijing Declaration on \"ending division and strengthening Palestinian unity\", according to state broadcaster CCTV.\n\nIsrael's Foreign Minister, Israel Katz, swiftly rejected the agreement on Tuesday, stating that no joint governance between Hamas and Fatah in Gaza will take place \"because Hamas's rule will be crushed\".\n\nThe two rival Palestinian groups, along with 12 other political factions, met Chinese foreign minister Wang Yi on Tuesday, concluding talks that started on Sunday.\n\nA joint statement issued after the most recent talks in Beijing gave no details on how or when the government would be formed, saying only that it would be done \"by agreement among the factions\".\n\nAccording to the joint statement, the two groups are committed to the creation of a Palestinian state on lands Israel captured in the 1967 Mideast war.\n\nWhile the groups have said they would work together many times before and failed, the signing of the declaration coincides with US Secretary of State Antony Blinken saying that a ceasefire between Israel and Hamas appears within sight.\n\nHamas routed Fatah forces in Gaza in a violent takeover of the territory in 2007.\n\nUnity efforts have been wrecked by the factions' own bitter rivalry over power and the West's "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://www.scmp.com/news/china/diplomacy/article/3271553/palestinian-factions-agree-end-division-pact-brokered-china", "title": "Palestinian factions agree to end division in pact brokered by China", "body": "Leaders of 14 factions sign Beijing Declaration calling for unity after talks in the Chinese capital\n\nRival Palestinian factions including Fatah and Hamas have signed an agreement aimed at ending their division and building unity following talks in Beijing, marking a diplomatic win for China.\n\nSenior representatives of 14 Palestinian factions reached the agreement \u2013 called the Beijing Declaration \u2013 after reconciliation talks that began on Sunday.\n\nThe pact aims to unite Palestinians in their conflict with Israel, which launched a war on militant group Hamas in Gaza in October.\n\nThe Chinese foreign ministry said the agreement was a first step to promote a \u201ccomprehensive, durable and sustainable ceasefire\u201d in the Gaza Strip that would eventually lead to Palestine being admitted to the United Nations as a fully fledged member and becoming an independent state.\n\nForeign Minister Wang Yi on Tuesday said the signing of the agreement was \u201can important, historic moment in the Palestinian cause\u201d.\n\nHe said that under the deal the rival groups had agreed to set up an \u201cinterim national reconciliation government\u201d to govern post-war Gaza.\n\nSignatories included senior Hamas official Mousa Abu Marzouk and Fatah envoy Mahmoud al-Aloul along with emissaries from 12 other Palestinian groups.\n\nThe Chinese foreign ministry said it was the first time the 14 rival groups had gathered together in Beijing for reconciliation talks.\n\n\u201cReconciliation is an internal matter for the Palestinian factions, but at the same time it cannot be achieved without the support of the international community,\u201d Wang said.\n\nHe added that China was keen to \u201cplay a constructive role in safeguarding peace and stability in the Middle East\u201d.\n\nHamas and the Palestinian Authority \u2013 the two dominant Palestinian political parties in the Palestinian territories \u2013 have held multiple rounds of unity talks since Hamas defeated President Mahmoud Abbas\u2019 Fatah party in parliamentary elections in 2006.\n\nIn 2007 Hamas became de facto ruler in the Gaza Strip while Fatah led the Palestinian Authority in the Israel-controlled West Bank.\n\nBut reconciliation efforts have floundered, with tensions between Fatah and Hamas escalating and spilling over in the region.\n\nHamas and Fatah have tried and failed several times to reach an agreement to unite the two separate Palestinian territories under one governance, with a 2017 agreement brokered by Egypt quickly falling apart. A 2022 agreement to hold elections within a year was not followed through.\n\nThe West has refused to accept any government that includes Hamas unless it expressly recognises Israel.\n\nTuesday\u2019s agreement comes as China has sought to position itself as a mediator in Gaza after it brokered a peace deal between Middle East rivals Iran and Saudi Arabia in March last year.\n\nIt is also trying to mediate in Russia\u2019s war in Ukraine. {"uri": "2024-07-430479702", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-23", "time": "06:28:14", "dateTime": "2024-07-23T06:28:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-23T05:48:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "https://www.wfxg.com/news/hamas-announces-national-unity-deal-with-palestinian-rivals/article_12ae6fdd-b912-519b-9c1b-0201e3f1a669.html", "title": "Hamas announces 'national unity' deal with Palestinian rivals", "body": "Hamas announced Tuesday it had signed an agreement in Beijing with other Palestinian organisations including rivals Fatah to work together for \"national unity\", with China describing it as a deal to rule Gaza together once the war ends.\n\nChinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi, who hosted senior Hamas official Musa Abu Marzuk, Fatah envoy Mahmud al-Aloul and emissaries from 12 other Palestinian groups, said they had agreed to set up an \"interim national reconciliation government\" to govern post-war Gaza.\n\n\"Today we sign an agreement for national unity and we say that the path to completing this journey is national unity. We are committed to national unity and we call for it,\" Abu Marzuk said after meeting Wang and the other envoys.\n\nThe announcement comes more than nine months into a war sparked by Hamas's October attack on southern Israel, which resulted in the deaths of 1,197 people, mostly civilians, according to an AFP tally based on Israeli figures.\n\nThe militants also seized 251 hostages, 116 of whom are still in Gaza, including 44 the Israeli military says are dead.\n\nIsrael's retaliatory military campaign in Gaza has killed more than 39,000 people, also mostly civilians, according to data from the health ministry in Hamas-run Gaza.\n\nThe relentless fighting has plunged Gaza into a severe humanitarian crisis.\n\nChina has sought to play a mediator role in the conflict, which has been rendered even more complex due to the intense rivalry between Hamas, which rules the Gaza Strip, and Fatah, which partially governs the occupied West Bank.\n\nIsrael has vowed to keep fighting until it destroys Hamas, and world powers including key Israeli backer the United States have scrambled to imagine scenarios for the governance of Gaza once the war ends.\n\nAs Tuesday's meeting wrapped up in Beijing, Wang said the groups had committed to \"reconciliation\".\n\n\"The most prominent highlight is the agreement to form an interim national reconciliation government around the governance of post-war Gaza,\" Wang said following the signing of the \"Beijing declaration\" by the factions in the Chinese capital.\n\n\"Reconciliation is an internal matter for the Palestinian factions, but at the same time, it cannot be achieved without the support of the international community,\" Wang said.\n\n- 'Peace and stability' -\n\nChina, he added, was keen to \"play a constructive role in safeguarding peace and stability in the Middle East\".\n\nBeijing, Wang said, called for a \"comprehensive, lasting and sustainable ceasefire\", as well as efforts to promote Palestinian self-governance and full recognition of a Palestinian state at the UN.\n\nHamas and Fatah have been bitter rivals since Hamas fighters ejected Fatah from the Gaza Strip after deadly clashes that followed Hamas's resounding victory in a 2006 election.\n\nFatah controls the Palestinian Authority, which has partial administrative control in the Israeli-occupied West Bank.\n\nSeveral reconciliation bids have failed, but calls have grown since the Hamas October attack and nine-month war in Gaza, with violence also soaring in the West Bank where Fatah is based.\n\nChina hosted Fatah and Hamas in April but a meeting scheduled for June was postponed.\n\nChina has historically been sympathetic to the Palestinian cause and supportive of a two-state solution to the Israeli-Palestinian {"uri": "8239046415", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-23", "time": "08:45:59", "dateTime": "2024-07-23T08:45:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-23T08:45:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "https://thearabweekly.com/hamas-fatah-announce-national-unity-deal-highlighting-chinas-enhanced-role", "title": "Hamas, Fatah announce 'national unity' deal highlighting China's enhanced role |  | AW", "body": "(L-R) Mahmoud al-Aloul, Vice-Chairman of the Central Committee of Palestinian Liberation Organisation and Fatah, China's Foreign Minister Wang Yi and Moussa Abu Marzouk, senior member of Hamas, in Beijing on July 23, 2024. AFP\n\nHamas announced on Tuesday it had signed an agreement in Beijing with other Palestinian organisations including rival Fatah to work together for \"national unity\", with China describing it as a deal to rule Gaza together once the war ends.\n\nIt remains to be seen whether this reconciliation attempt will succeed while others have failed.\n\nChinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi, who hosted senior Hamas official Moussa Abu Marzouk, Fatah envoy Mahmoud al-Aloul and emissaries from 12 other Palestinian groups, said they had agreed to set up an \"interim national reconciliation government\" to administer post-war Gaza.\n\n\"Today we sign an agreement for national unity and we say that the path to completing this journey is national unity. We are committed to national unity and we call for it,\" Abu Marzouk said after meeting Wang and the other envoys.\n\nWang called it an \"historic moment for the cause of Palestine's liberation.\"\n\nThe announcement comes more than nine months into the war in Gaza highlighting China's quest for an enhanced role in the Middle East since it secured a Saudi-Iranian rapprochement in March 2023.\n\nBeijing has since sought to play a mediator role in the Gaza war and post-conflict preparations. Its efforts have been complicated by the intense rivalry between Hamas, which rules the Gaza Strip, and Fatah, which partially governs the occupied West Bank.\n\nIsrael has vowed to keep fighting until it destroys Hamas, and world powers including key Israeli backer the United States have scrambled to ponder scenarios for the governance of Gaza once the war ends. Washington would like the PA to play a leading role in managing Gaza after the war. Israel does not want Hamas nor the Palestinian Authority to rule the enclave once the war is over.\n\nAs Tuesday's meeting wrapped up in Beijing, Wang said the groups had committed to \"reconciliation\".\n\n\"The most prominent highlight is the agreement to form an interim national reconciliation government around the governance of post-war Gaza,\" Wang said following the signing of the \"Beijing declaration\" by the factions in the Chinese capital.\n\n\"Reconciliation is an internal matter for the Palestinian factions, but at the same time, it cannot be achieved without the support of the international community,\" Wang said.\n\nChina, he added, was keen to \"play a constructive role in safeguarding peace and stability in the Middle East\".\n\nBeijing, Wang said, called for a \"comprehensive, lasting and sustainable ceasefire\", as well as efforts to promote Palestinian self-governance and full recognition of a Palestinian state at the UN.\n\nHamas and Fatah have been bitter rivals since Hamas fighters ejected Fatah from the Gaza Strip after deadly clashes that followed the resounding Hamas victory in a 2006 election.\n\nFatah controls the Palestinian Authority, which has partial administrative control in the Israeli-occupied West Bank.\n\nSeveral reconciliation bids have failed leading many regional experts to be sceptical about the prospects for success of the announced \"reconciliation\". But calls have grown for inter-Palestinian entente since the Hamas October attack and nine-month war in Gaza, with violence also soaring in the West Bank where Fatah is based.\n\nChina had hosted Fatah and Hamas in April but a meeting scheduled for June was postponed.\n\nChina has historically been sympathetic to the Palestinian cause and supportive of a two-state solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.\n\nThe deal iwas announced amid ongoing war in Gaza, which has killed so far more than 39,000 Palestinian in the enclave, mostly civilians, according to data from the health ministry in Gaza.\n\nThe brutal war has also plunged Gaza into a severe humanitarian crisis.\n\nThe conflict was sparked by Hamas' October attack on southern Israel, which resulted in the deaths of 1,197 people, mostly civilians, according to Israeli figures. The militants also seized 251 hostages. Mediation has so far failed to produce a ceasefire or the release of the hostages.", "source": {"uri": "thearabweekly.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "AW"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": We are committed to national unity and we call for it,\" Abu Marzuk said after meeting Wang and the other envoys.\n\nThe announcement comes more than nine months into a war sparked by Hamas's October attack on southern Israel, which resulted in the deaths of 1,197 people, mostly civilians, according to an AFP tally based on Israeli figures.\n\nThe militants also seized 251 hostages, 116 of whom are still in Gaza, including 44 the Israeli military says are dead.\n\nIsrael's retaliatory military campaign in Gaza has killed more than 39,000 people, also mostly civilians, according to data from the health ministry in Hamas-run Gaza.\n\nThe relentless fighting has plunged Gaza into a severe humanitarian crisis.\n\nChina has sought to play a mediator role in the conflict, which has been rendered even more complex due to the intense rivalry between Hamas, which rules the Gaza Strip, and Fatah, which partially governs the occupied West Bank.\n\nIsrael has vowed to keep fighting until {"uri": "8239336064", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-23", "time": "11:44:32", "dateTime": "2024-07-23T11:44:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-23T11:43:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "https://www.pehalnews.in/latest/chinese-state-media-reports-hamas-and-fatah-agreement-to-end-rift-in-beijing-signing/3421/", "title": "Chinese state media reports Hamas and Fatah agreement to end rift in Beijing signing - Pehal News", "body": "Palestinian factions Hamas and Fatah signed a declaration in Beijing on ending a yearslong rift, the groups said Tuesday, taking a step toward resolving a deep divide which has lingered for years despite repeated attempts at unifying the sides. The two heavyweights of Palestinian politics signed the Beijing Declaration on \"ending division and strengthening Palestinian unity,\" according to Chinese state broadcaster CCTV, pledging to form a unity government for the Palestinian territories. But previous such declarations have failed, including a similar deal in 2011, casting doubt over whether the China-sponsored negotiations might actually lead to a resolution.\n\nThe declaration comes at a sensitive time, as the war in Gaza rages on into its 10th month and as Israel and Hamas are weighing an internationally backed cease-fire proposal that would wind down the war and free dozens of Israeli hostages held by Hamas. The question of Palestinian political unity could complicate planning for a postwar leadership structure for Gaza, one of the thornier issues in the ongoing peace talks.\n\nSince the current war broke out in Gaza almost 10 months ago, Hamas officials have said that the party does not want to return to ruling Gaza as it did before the conflict, and the group has called for formation of a government of technocrats to be agreed upon by the various Palestinian factions, which would prepare the way for elections for both Gaza and the West Bank, with the intention of forming a unified government. But both Israel and the PA have deep distrusts about Hamas' intentions. Israel's Foreign Minister, Israel Katz, swiftly rejected the agreement Tuesday, stating that no joint governance between Hamas and Fatah in Gaza will take place \"because Hamas's rule will be crushed.\"\n\nThe two rival Palestinian groups, along with 12 other political factions, met with Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi, concluding talks that started Sunday. The agreement also underscores China's growing role in Middle East diplomacy, with success in the restoration of relations between Saudi Arabia and Iran.\n\nA joint statement issued after the most recent talks in Beijing gave no details on how or when the government would be formed, saying only that it would be done \"by agreement among the factions.\" According to the joint statement, the two groups are committed to the creation of a Palestinian state on lands Israel captured in the 1967 Mideast war.\n\nThe deal does not appear to bridge the two group's diverging position on Israel. Hamas previously said it would accept a state based on the pre-1967 war borders, while also refusing to officially recognize Israel. The Fatah-dominated Palestinian Authority, meanwhile, abides by interim peace agreements with Israel signed in the early 1990s. The agreement signed by the Palestinian factions promised to follow up on previous reconciliation agreements signed in both 2011 and 2022.\n\n\"The understanding in China is based on widening the scope of the membership on the PLO (Palestine Liberation Organization) to include other factions who have not joined it\" including Hamas, said Jamal Nazzal, a Fatah spokesperson. \"It's a long way ahead, and most of it will be implemented after a possible cease-fire,\" he added.\n\nFatah and Hamas have been rivals since Hamas violently routed forces loyal to Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas' Fatah in Gaza in 2007, taking over the impoverished coastal enclave. The Fatah-dominated Palestinian Authority, headed by Abbas, administers parts of the occupied West Bank. It is widely viewed by the Palestinian public as corrupt, out of touch, and a subcontractor for Israel because of their joint security coordination.\n\nHamas members have never been part of PLO, the Palestinian government body responsible for international affairs. In a statement, Husam Badran, a Hamas political official based in Qatar, praised the agreement, describing it as a further \"positive step towards achieving Palestinian national unity.\" But Tuesday's deal doesn't have a hard timeline.\n\n\"There is an opportunity ... but it is not big, because it lacks a specific timetable for implementation,\" said Hani Al-Masry, an expert on Palestinian reconciliation affairs. Repeated attempts at mending the rift have failed, wrecked by the factions' own bitter rivalry over power and the West's refusal to accept any government that includes Hamas unless it expressly recognizes Israel.\n\nUnited States President Joe Biden's administration envisions a revamped Palestinian Authority ruling postwar Gaza and has sought a series of reforms that might make it a viable presence in the war-ravaged territory. Israel rejected that idea, but has not put forward a credible alternative for who will govern Gaza. The Palestinian Islamic Jihad, a smaller militant group allied with Hamas, issued a statement Tuesday after the talks saying that it still \"rejects any formula that includes recognition of Israel explicitly or implicitly\" and that it had \"demanded the withdrawal of the Palestine Liberation Organization's recognition of Israel.\"\n\nGoldenberg reported from Tel Aviv, Israel; Wu reported from Bangkok. Abby Sewell contributed to this report from Beirut.", "source": {"uri": "pehalnews.in", "dataType": "news", "title": "Pehal News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri":
