{"uri": "2024-07-430533826", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-23", "time": "07:25:41", "dateTime": "2024-07-23T07:25:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-23T07:12:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "https://www.ibtimes.com.au/hamas-announces-national-unity-deal-palestinian-rivals-1849843", "title": "Hamas Announces 'National Unity' Deal With Palestinian Rivals", "body": "Hamas announced Tuesday it had signed an agreement in Beijing with other Palestinian organisations including rivals Fatah to work together for \"national unity\", with China describing it as a deal to rule Gaza together once the war ends.\n\nChinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi, who hosted senior Hamas official Musa Abu Marzuk, Fatah envoy Mahmud al-Aloul and emissaries from 12 other Palestinian groups, said they had agreed to set up an \"interim national reconciliation government\" to govern post-war Gaza.\n\n\"Today we sign an agreement for national unity and we say that the path to completing this journey is national unity. We are committed to national unity and we call for it,\" Abu Marzuk said after meeting Wang and the other envoys.\n\nThe announcement comes more than nine months into a war sparked by Hamas's October attack on southern Israel, which resulted in the deaths of 1,197 people, mostly civilians, according to an AFP tally based on Israeli figures.\n\nThe militants also seized 251 hostages, 116 of whom are still in Gaza, including 44 the Israeli military says are dead.\n\nIsrael's retaliatory military campaign in Gaza has killed more than 39,000 people, also mostly civilians, according to data from the health ministry in Hamas-run Gaza.\n\nThe relentless fighting has plunged Gaza into a severe humanitarian crisis.\n\nChina has sought to play a mediator role in the conflict, which has been rendered even more complex due to the intense rivalry between Hamas, which rules the Gaza Strip, and Fatah, which partially governs the occupied West Bank.\n\nIsrael has vowed to keep fighting until it destroys Hamas, and world powers including key Israeli backer the United States have scrambled to imagine scenarios for the governance of Gaza once the war ends.\n\nNeither Israel nor the United States would sanction any post-war plan that includes Hamas, which is proscribed as a terrorist organisation by Washington.\n\nWhile it is unclear whether the deal announced in Beijing on Tuesday can hold, it does indicate that the only world power that can engineer a rapprochement between the Palestinian rivals is China.\n\nAs Tuesday's meeting wrapped up in Beijing, Wang said the groups had committed to \"reconciliation\".\n\n\"The most prominent highlight is the agreement to form an interim national reconciliation government around the governance of post-war Gaza,\" Wang said after the factions signed the \"Beijing declaration\" in the Chinese capital.\n\n\"Reconciliation is an internal matter for the Palestinian factions, but at the same time, it cannot be achieved without the support of the international community,\" Wang said.\n\nFatah official Mahmoud al-Aloul thanked China for its \"unending support\" for the Palestinian cause.\n\n\"To China, you have our love, you have all our friendship, from all the Palestinian people,\" he said.\n\nNotably, he did not mention whether any agreement had been reached with Hamas and the other factions.\n\nAlso present at Tuesday's meeting were envoys from Egypt, Algeria and Russia, according to Wang.\n\nEgypt, which neighbours Israel and Gaza, is a key mediator in the conflict.\n\nAlgeria is a non-permanent member of the UN Security Council, and has drafted resolutions on the war.\n\nAnd while Western powers have sought to isolate Russia over its Ukraine invasion, China has maintained its strategic partnership with Moscow.\n\nChina, Wang said, was keen to \"play a constructive role in safeguarding peace and stability in the Middle East\".\n\nHe also called for a \"comprehensive, lasting and sustainable ceasefire\", as well as efforts to promote Palestinian self-governance and full recognition of a Palestinian state at the UN.\n\nHamas and Fatah have been bitter rivals since Hamas fighters ejected Fatah from the Gaza Strip after deadly clashes that followed Hamas's resounding victory in a 2006 election.\n\nFatah controls the Palestinian Authority, which has partial administrative control in the Israeli-occupied West Bank.\n\nSeveral reconciliation bids have failed, but calls have grown since the Hamas October attack and nine-month war in Gaza, with violence also soaring in the West Bank where Fatah is based.\n\nChina hosted Fatah and Hamas in April but a meeting scheduled for June was postponed.\n\nChina has positioned itself as a more neutral actor on the Israel-Palestinian conflict than its rival the United States, advocating for a two-state solution while also maintaining good ties with Israel.\n\nAnd it has sought to play a greater role in the Middle East in recent years, facilitating last year's historic rapprochement between Saudi Arabia and Iran.", "source": {"uri": "ibtimes.com.au", "dataType": "news", "title": "International Business Times AU"}, "authors": [], attack on southern Israel, which resulted in the deaths of 1,197 people, mostly civilians, according to an AFP tally based on Israeli figures.\n\nThe militants also seized 251 hostages, 116 of whom cause and supportive of a two-state solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.\n\nChina has positioned itself as a more neutral actor on the Israel-Palestinian conflict than its rival the United {"uri": "2024-07-430692997", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-23", "time": "09:52:51", "dateTime": "2024-07-23T09:52:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-23T06:06:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://tribtown.com/2024/07/23/hamas-and-fatah-sign-declaration-in-beijing-on-ending-yearslong-rift-as-war-rages-in-gaza/", "title": "Hamas and Fatah sign declaration in Beijing on ending yearslong rift as war rages in Gaza", "body": "RAMALLAH, West Bank (AP) -- Palestinian factions Hamas and Fatah signed a declaration in Beijing on ending a yearslong rift, Chinese state media said Tuesday, taking a step toward potentially resolving the deep divide between the sides as the war in Gaza rages on.\n\nThe declaration by the two heavyweights of Palestinian politics -- and other smaller Palestinian groups -- to form a unity government for the Palestinian territories is the result of the latest in a series of talks meant to unite the sides.\n\nBut previous declarations have failed, including a similar deal in 2011, casting doubt over whether the China-sponsored negotiations might actually lead to a resolution. It also comes as Israel and Hamas are weighing an internationally backed cease-fire proposal that would wind down the nine-month war and free dozens of Israeli hostages held by Hamas.\n\nStill, the future of Gaza is undecided, with Israel vehemently opposed to any role by Hamas in governing Gaza. It has also rejected calls from the United States for the Fatah-dominated Palestinian Authority to run Gaza after the war ends. The lack of a postwar vision for running the Gaza Strip has complicated negotiations over a cease-fire.\n\nSince the current war broke out in Gaza almost 10 months ago, Hamas officials have said that the party does not want to return to ruling Gaza as it did before the conflict, and the group has called for formation of a government of technocrats to be agreed upon by the various Palestinian factions, which would prepare the way for elections for both Gaza and the West Bank, with the intention of forming a unified government.\n\nThe two groups signed the Beijing Declaration on \"ending division and strengthening Palestinian unity,\" according to state broadcaster CCTV.\n\nIsrael's Foreign Minister, Israel Katz, swiftly rejected the agreement Tuesday, stating that no joint governance between Hamas and Fatah in Gaza will take place \"because Hamas's rule will be crushed.\"\n\nThe two rival Palestinian groups, along with 12 other political factions, met with Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi, concluding talks that started Sunday, according to a post on social media platform Weibo from Chinese TV network CGTN.\n\nThe agreement also underscores China's growing role in Middle East diplomacy, with success in the restoration of relations between Saudi Arabia and Iran.\n\n\"But to be sure, China is still the process of trying to earn credibility as a global mediator,\" said James Char, a research fellow at the Institute of Defence and Strategic Studies at Nanyang Technological University in Singapore.\n\nA joint statement issued after the most recent talks in Beijing gave no details on how or when the government would be formed, saying only that it would be done \"by agreement among the factions.\" According to the joint statement, the two groups are committed to the creation of a Palestinian state on lands Israel captured in the 1967 Mideast war.\n\nThe deal does not appear to bridge the two group's diverging position on Israel. Hamas previously said it would accept a state based on 1967 borders, while also refusing to officially recognize Israel. The Fatah-dominated Palestinian Authority, meanwhile, abides by interim peace agreements with Israel signed in the early 1990s.\n\nThe agreement signed by the Palestinian factions promised to follow up on previous reconciliation agreements signed in both 2011 and 2022.\n\n\"The understanding in China is based on widening the scope of the membership on the PLO (Palestine Liberation Organization) to include other factions who have not joined it\" including Hamas, said Jamal Nazzal, a Fatah spokesperson.\n\n\"It's a long way ahead, and most of it will be implemented after a possible cease-fire,\" he added.\n\nFatah and Hamas have been rivals since Hamas violently routed forces loyal to Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas' Fatah in Gaza in 2007, taking over the impoverished coastal enclave. The Fatah-dominated Palestinian Authority, headed by Abbas, administers parts of the occupied West Bank. It is widely viewed by the Palestinian public as corrupt, out of touch, and a subcontractor for Israel because of their joint security coordination.\n\nHamas members have never been part of PLO, the Palestinian government body responsible for international affairs. In a statement, Husam Badran, a Hamas political official based in Qatar, praised the agreement, describing it as a further \"positive step towards achieving Palestinian national unity.\"\n\nBut Tuesday's deal doesn't have a hard timeline.\n\n\"There is an opportunity ... but it is not big, because it lacks a specific timetable for implementation,\" said Hani Al-Masry, an expert on Palestinian reconciliation affairs.\n\nRepeated attempts at mending the rift have failed, wrecked by the factions' own bitter rivalry over power and the West's refusal to accept any government that includes Hamas unless it expressly recognizes Israel.\n\nUnited States President Joe Biden's administration envisions a revamped Palestinian Authority to rule postwar Gaza and has sought a series of reforms that might make it a viable presence in the war-ravaged territory. Israel rejected that idea, but has not put forward a credible alternative for who will govern Gaza.\n\nThe Palestinian Islamic Jihad, a smaller militant group allied with Hamas, issued a statement Tuesday after the talks saying that it still \"rejects any formula that includes recognition of Israel explicitly or implicitly\" and that it had \"demanded the withdrawal of the Palestine Liberation Organization's recognition of Israel.\"\n\n___\n\nGoldenberg reported from Tel Aviv, Israel; Wu reported from Bangkok. "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://jerseyeveningpost.com/morenews/worldnews/2024/07/23/hamas-and-fatah-sign-declaration-to-form-future-government-as-war-rages-in-gaza/", "title": "Hamas and Fatah sign declaration to form future government as war rages in Gaza", "body": "Palestinian factions Hamas and Fatah have signed a declaration vowing to form a government together.\n\nThe event, hosted by China, is the latest attempt at resolving the years-long rivalry between the two groups.\n\nBoth sides said the accord, which provided no guarantees or timeline, was only an initial step.\n\nPrevious such declarations have failed, raising doubt over whether the China-sponsored negotiations might lead to a resolution between Hamas, which has ruled the Gaza Strip for the past 17 years, and Fatah, the main force in the US-backed Palestinian Authority that administers parts of the occupied West Bank.\n\nChinese state broadcaster CCTV announced that the two sides and other, smaller Palestinian factions signed the Beijing Declaration on \"ending division and strengthening Palestinian unity\", pledging to form a unity government for the Palestinian territories.\n\nThe agreement offered only broad outlines of how they would work together.\n\n\"There is an opportunity ... but it is not big, because it lacks a specific timetable for implementation,\" said Hani Al-Masry, an expert on Palestinian reconciliation affairs.\n\nOne of the thorniest issues is the question of who will run Gaza after the war -- and the unity efforts are in part motivated by Palestinians' desire to offer a scenario for post-war rule.\n\nBut Israel vehemently opposes any role for Hamas, which it has vowed to destroy after its October 7 attack on southern Israel.\n\nIt also has rejected US calls for the Palestinian Authority to govern Gaza after the fighting ends, though it has not presented a cohesive post-war vision of its own.\n\nPalestinian President Mahmoud Abbas's Fatah has been deeply reluctant to share power with its long-time rival.\n\nHamas won Palestinian parliamentary elections in 2006. The following year, amid escalating tensions, Hamas routed forces loyal to Abbas in Gaza. It has ruled the impoverished coastal enclave ever since.\n\nThat government would then prepare for elections in Gaza and the West Bank, with the intention of forming a unified government.\n\nReacting to the announcement out of China, Israel's foreign minister said no joint governance between Hamas and Fatah in Gaza will take place \"because Hamas' rule will be crushed\".\n\nThe agreement also underscored China's attempts to have a growing role in Middle East diplomacy, after its success in mediating the restoration of relations between Saudi Arabia and Iran.\n\n\"To be sure, China is still in the process of trying to earn credibility as a global mediator,\" said James Char, a research fellow at the Institute of Defence and Strategic Studies at Nanyang Technological University in Singapore.\n\nOfficials from Fatah, Hamas and 12 other factions met with Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi, concluding talks that started Sunday, according to a post on social media platform Weibo from Chinese TV network CGTN.\n\nIt said they promised to follow up on previous reconciliation agreements signed in 2011 and 2022.\n\nIn the statement, all the factions, including Hamas, said they were committed to the creation of a Palestinian state on lands Israel captured in the 1967 Mideast war.\n\nHamas, whose original charter directly called for Israel's destruction, has said it would accept a Palestinian state based on the pre-1967 war borders but refuses to officially recognise Israel.\n\nThe Palestinian Authority, meanwhile, has recognised Israel and works within the framework of peace deals signed in the early 1990s.\n\nThose deals were supposed to lead to an eventual state in the West Bank and Gaza, but talks have been defunct for years, leaving it in charge of only isolated West Bank enclaves.\n\nThe unity announcement is based on widening the membership of the Fatah-led Palestine Liberation Organisation (PLO), including Hamas, said Jamal Nazzal, a Fatah spokesperson.\n\n\"It's a long way ahead, and most of it will be implemented after a possible ceasefire,\" he added.\n\nHamas members have never been part of the PLO, the umbrella group of Palestinian factions that undergirds the Palestinian Authority.\n\nHusam Badran, a Hamas political official based in Qatar, called the agreement a further \"positive step towards achieving Palestinian national unity\".\n\nUS President Joe Biden's administration envisions a revamped Palestinian Authority ruling post-war Gaza and has sought reforms that might make it a viable presence in the war-ravaged territory. However, Israel rejected that idea.\n\nThe Palestinian Islamic Jihad, a smaller militant group allied with Hamas, issued a statement after the talks saying it still \"rejects any formula that includes {"uri": "8239280048", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-23", "time": "11:10:08", "dateTime": "2024-07-23T11:10:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-23T11:09:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://www.theglobeandmail.com/world/article-palestinian-factions-agree-to-form-unity-government-after-talks-in/", "title": "Palestinian factions agree to form unity government after talks in China", "body": "Palestinian factions including rivals Hamas and Fatah agreed to end their divisions and form an interim national unity government during negotiations in China that ended on Tuesday, China's foreign ministry said.\n\nThe Beijing Declaration was signed at the closing ceremony of a reconciliation dialogue among 14 Palestinian factions held in China's capital from July 21-23, according to the readout.\n\nPrevious efforts by Egypt and other Arab countries to reconcile Hamas and Fatah have failed to end 17 years of power-sharing conflict that have weakened Palestinian political aspirations, and it remains to be seen whether this deal will survive the realities on the ground.\n\nThe meeting was held amid attempts by international mediators to reach a ceasefire deal for Gaza, with one of the sticking points being the \"day-after\" plan - how the Hamas-run enclave will be governed once the war that began on Oct. 7 ends.\n\nSenior Hamas official Hussam Badran said the most important point of the Beijing Declaration was to form a Palestinian national unity government to manage the affairs of Palestinians.\n\n\"This creates a formidable barrier against all regional and international interventions that seek to impose realities against our people's interests in managing Palestinian affairs post-war,\" Badran said.\n\nIsraeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has said his goal is to destroy the Iran-backed Hamas group and opposes it having any role in a post war Gaza administration.\n\n\"Instead of rejecting terrorism, (Fatah leader) Mahmoud Abbas embraces the murderers and rapists of Hamas, revealing his true face. In reality, this won't happen because Hamas' rule will be crushed, and Abbas will be watching Gaza from afar. Israel's security will remain solely in Israel's hands,\" Israeli Foreign Minister Israel Katz said on X.\n\nBadran said the national unity government would manage the affairs of Palestinians in Gaza and the West Bank, oversee reconstruction, and prepare conditions for elections.\n\nCurrently Hamas runs Gaza and Fatah forms the backbone of the Palestinian Authority, which has limited control in the Israeli-occupied West Bank. There has been no immediate comment from Fatah.\n\nDetails of the agreement did not set out a timeframe for forming a new government. In March, Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas, who heads Fatah, appointed a new government led by one of his close aides, Mohammad Mustafa.\n\nNonetheless, the agreement marks a diplomatic coup for Beijing and its growing influence in the Middle East, after it brokered a breakthrough peace deal between longstanding regional foes Saudi Arabia and Iran last year.\n\n\"The core achievement is to make it clear that the Palestine Liberation Organization is the sole legitimate representative of the Palestinian people,\" Chinese foreign minister Wang Yi said during the closing ceremony, according to the readout.\n\n\"China sincerely hopes that the Palestinian factions will achieve Palestinian independence at an early date on the basis of internal reconciliation, and is willing to strengthen communication and coordination with relevant parties to jointly work to implement the Beijing Declaration reached today.\"\n\nThe most \"prominent highlight\" was the agreement on forming an interim national reconciliation government around the post-war governance of Gaza, Wang said, adding that the international community should support efforts to form an interim Palestinian government to control Gaza and the West Bank.\n\nHamas and Islamic Jihad are not members of the PLO, the Palestinians' highest decision-making body, but they demand that any unity deal includes holding an election for the PLO parliament to secure their inclusion. The Islamist groups are at odds with the current PLO over peace accords with Israel.\n\n\"This declaration comes at an important time as our people are facing a genocidal war, especially in the Gaza Strip,\" a statement quoted Badran as saying.\n\nRival factions Hamas and Fatah first met in Beijing in April to discuss reconciliation efforts to end around 17 years of disputes, the first time a Hamas delegation was publicly known to have visited China since the war in Gaza began.\n\nThe second round of talks, originally planned for last month, were delayed as both factions traded blame.\n\nThe long-feuding Palestinian factions have previously failed to heal their political disputes after Hamas fighters expelled Fatah from Gaza in a short war in 2007.\n\nChinese officials have ramped up advocacy for the Palestinians in international forums in recent months, calling for a larger-scale Israeli-Palestinian peace conference and a specific timetable to implement a two-state solution.", "source": {"uri": "theglobeandmail.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Globe and Mail"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Palestinians", "type": {"uri": "8239237358", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-23", "time": "10:43:35", "dateTime": "2024-07-23T10:43:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-23T10:42:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://www.cnbc.com/2024/07/23/palestinian-rivals-hamas-and-fatah-sign-reconciliation-agreement-in-china-.html", "title": "Palestinian rivals Hamas and Fatah sign reconciliation agreement in China", "body": "(L-R) Mahmoud al-Aloul, Vice Chairman of the Central Committee of Palestinian organisation and political party Fatah, China's Foreign Minister Wang Yi, and Mussa Abu Marzuk, senior member of the Palestinian Islamist movement Hamas, attend an event at the Diaoyutai State Guesthouse in Beijing on July 23, 2024. China's Foreign Minister Wang Yi on July 23 hailed an agreement by 14 Palestinian factions to set up an \"interim national reconciliation government\" to govern Gaza after the war.\n\nRival Palestinian factions Hamas and Fatah agreed to end their long-standing enmity and work to form a national unity government following talks held in China, Chinese state media reported Tuesday.\n\n\"On the morning of July 23, the closing ceremony of the reconciliation dialogue among Palestinian factions was held in Beijing. Representatives of Palestinian factions signed the 'Beijing Declaration' on ending division and strengthening Palestinian unity,\" Chinese state media outlet CGTN wrote in a post on local social media platform Weibo, according to a translation provided by the website and vetted by CNBC.\n\nThe \"inter-Palestinian reconciliation dialogue,\" as it was described by the state outlet, had been underway in Beijing since Sunday.\n\nThis marks a significant development, as Hamas and Fatah have been bitter enemies ever since the bloody 2006-2007 civil war in the Gaza Strip. Fatah, the Palestinian political party then governed both the West Bank and the Gaza enclave at the time, was violently kicked out of the latter territory, following Hamas' election win in the Strip in 2006.\n\nHamas has governed the Gaza enclave since then and is currently embroiled in a brutal war with Israel. The offensive was triggered by the Hamas-led terror attacks of Oct. 7, which resulted in 1,200 deaths in Israel, with a further 253 people taken hostage by Hamas into the Gaza Strip, according to Israeli tallies. The Palestinian militant group is designated as a terrorist organization by the U.S. and U.K.\n\nIn the months since, Israel's retaliatory assaults on the Gaza Strip have killed nearly 39,000 Palestinians there, according to health authorities in the enclave.\n\nHussam Badran, a senior Hamas official taking part in the talks, said in a statement cited by Reuters that \"this declaration comes at an important time\" amid Israel's war in Gaza, and that the agreement was an \"additional positive step towards achieving Palestinian national unity.\"\n\nFatah, formally called the Palestinian National Liberation Movement, is led by Mahmoud Abbas, the President of the Palestinian Authority (PA). The PA, and Fatah as its dominant party, govern the West Bank -- a Palestinian territory occupied by Israel.\n\nChinese state media hailed the agreement, saying it was signed by 14 Palestinian factions, while Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi called it a \"historic moment for the cause of Palestine's liberation.\"\n\nBut this is far from the first time that Hamas and Fatah have signed reconciliation pacts, only to return to hostilities due to persisting disagreements.\n\n\"Before everyone gets excited and files a batch of stories about China as the Middle East's new diplomatic power: a reminder that, since 2006, Hamas and Fatah also signed reconciliation agreements in Algiers, Cairo, Doha, Mecca and Sana'a, none of which actually reconciled them,\" Gregg Carlstrom, author of the book \"How Long Will Israel Survive? The Threat From Within,\" wrote in a post on X.\n\nWhile statements following the talks highlighted the signatories' consensus on building an interim unity government that would be established with China's support, long-time observers of the region noted that meetings and declarations will not determine success for the diplomatic efforts.\n\n\"Since 2007, there have been numerous rounds of negotiation and even provisional agreements aimed at reconciliation but they have all failed,\" Taufiq Rahim, principal at 2040 Advisory and author of \"Middle East in Crisis & Conflict: A Primer,\" told CNBC.\n\n\"The devil is not in the details but the implementation,\" he said. \"Given the many uncertainties on the ground and the upcoming US elections the deal could be upended easily.\"\n\nChina has increasingly moved to expand its role in international diplomacy, making world headlines in March of 2023 when it helped broker a historic normalization agreement between then-adversaries Iran and Saudi Arabia.", "source": {"uri": "cnbc.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "CNBC"}, "authors": [{"uri": "natasha_turak@cnbc.com", "name": "Natasha Turak", "type": "author", We are committed to national unity and we call for it,\"\n\nAbu Marzuk said after meeting Wang and the other envoys. The announcement comes more than nine months into the genocide.\n\nIsrael's retaliatory military campaign in Gaza has killed more than 39,000 people, also mostly civilians, according to data from the health ministry in Gaza.\n\nThe relentless fighting has plunged Gaza into a severe humanitarian crisis. China has sought to play a mediator role in the conflict, which has been rendered even more complex due to the intense rivalry between Hamas, which rules the Gaza Strip, and Fatah, which partially governs the occupied West Bank.\n\nIsrael has vowed to keep fighting until it destroys Hamas, and world powers, including key Israeli backer the United States, have scrambled to imagine scenarios for the governance of Gaza once the war ends. As Tuesday's meeting wrapped up in Beijing, Wang said the groups had committed to \"reconciliation\".\n\n\"The most prominent highlight is the agreement to form an interim national reconciliation government around the governance of post-war Gaza,\" Wang said following the signing of the \"Beijing Declaration\" by the factions in the Chinese capital.\n\n\"Reconciliation is an internal matter for the Palestinian factions, but at the same time, it cannot be achieved without the support of the international community,\" Wang said. China, he added, was keen to \"play a constructive role in safeguarding peace and stability in the Middle East\". Beijing, Wang said, called for a \"comprehensive, lasting and sustainable ceasefire\", as well as efforts to promote Palestinian self-governance and full recognition of a Palestinian state at the UN.\n\nHamas and Fatah have been bitter rivals since Hamas fighters ejected Fatah from the Gaza Strip after deadly clashes that followed Hamas's resounding victory in a 2006 election.\n\nFatah controls the Palestinian Authority, which has partial administrative control in the Israeli-occupied West Bank. Several reconciliation bids have failed, but calls have grown since October 7, with violence also soaring in the West Bank, where Fatah is based.\n\nChina hosted Fatah and Hamas in April, but a meeting scheduled for June was postponed. China has historically been sympathetic to the Palestinian cause and supportive of a two-state solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.", "source": {"uri": "thecurrent.pk", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8239185708", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-23", "time": "10:16:31", "dateTime": "2024-07-23T10:16:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-23T10:12:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://www.ndtv.com/world-news/hamas-announces-deal-with-palestinian-rivals-for-national-unity-in-beijing-6169606", "title": "Hamas Announces Deal With Palestinian Rivals For 'National Unity' In Beijing", "body": "Neither Israel nor the United States would sanction any post-war plan that includes Hamas, which is proscribed as a terrorist organisation by Washington.\n\nThe announcement comes more than nine months into a war sparked by Hamas' October attack on Israel (file)\n\nBeijing, China:\n\nHamas announced Tuesday it had signed an agreement in Beijing with other Palestinian organisations including rivals Fatah to work together for \"national unity\", with China describing it as a deal to rule Gaza together once the war ends.\n\nChinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi, who hosted senior Hamas official Musa Abu Marzuk, Fatah envoy Mahmud al-Aloul and emissaries from 12 other Palestinian groups, said they had agreed to set up an \"interim national reconciliation government\" to govern post-war Gaza.\n\n\"Today we sign an agreement for national unity and we say that the path to completing this journey is national unity. We are committed to national unity and we call for it,\" Abu Marzuk said after meeting Wang and the other envoys.\n\nThe announcement comes more than nine months into a war sparked by Hamas's October attack on southern Israel, which resulted in the deaths of 1,197 people, mostly civilians, according to an AFP tally based on Israeli figures.\n\nThe operatives also seized 251 hostages, 116 of whom are still in Gaza, including 44 the Israeli military says are dead.\n\nIsrael's retaliatory military campaign in Gaza has killed more than 39,000 people, also mostly civilians, according to data from the health ministry in Hamas-run Gaza.\n\nThe relentless fighting has plunged Gaza into a severe humanitarian crisis.\n\nChina has sought to play a mediator role in the conflict, which has been rendered even more complex due to the intense rivalry between Hamas, which rules the Gaza Strip, and Fatah, which partially governs the occupied West Bank.\n\nIsrael has vowed to keep fighting until it destroys Hamas, and world powers including key Israeli backer the United States have scrambled to imagine scenarios for the governance of Gaza once the war ends.\n\nNeither Israel nor the United States would sanction any post-war plan that includes Hamas, which is proscribed as a terrorist organisation by Washington.\n\nWhile it is unclear whether the deal announced in Beijing on Tuesday can hold, it does indicate that the only world power that can engineer a rapprochement between the Palestinian rivals is China.\n\nAs Tuesday's meeting wrapped up in Beijing, Wang said the groups had committed to \"reconciliation\".\n\n\"The most prominent highlight is the agreement to form an interim national reconciliation government around the governance of post-war Gaza,\" Wang said after the factions signed the \"Beijing Declaration\" in the Chinese capital.\n\n\"Reconciliation is an internal matter for the Palestinian factions, but at the same time, it cannot be achieved without the support of the international community,\" Wang said.\n\nFatah official Mahmoud al-Aloul thanked China for its \"unending support\" for the Palestinian cause.\n\n\"To China, you have our love, you have all our friendship, from all the Palestinian people,\" he said.\n\nNotably, he did not mention whether any agreement had been reached with Hamas and the other factions.\n\nAlso present at Tuesday's meeting were envoys from Egypt, Algeria and Russia, according to Wang.\n\nEgypt, which neighbours Israel and Gaza, is a key mediator in the conflict.\n\nAlgeria is a non-permanent member of the UN Security Council and has drafted resolutions on the war.\n\nAnd while Western powers have sought to isolate Russia over its Ukraine invasion, China has maintained its strategic partnership with Moscow.\n\n'Peace and stability'\n\nChina, Wang said, was keen to \"play a constructive role in safeguarding peace and stability in the Middle East\".\n\nHe also called for a \"comprehensive, lasting and sustainable ceasefire\", as well as efforts to promote Palestinian self-governance and full recognition of a Palestinian state at the UN.\n\nHamas and Fatah have been bitter rivals since Hamas fighters ejected Fatah from the Gaza Strip after deadly clashes that followed Hamas's resounding victory in a 2006 election.\n\nFatah controls the Palestinian Authority, which has partial administrative control in the Israeli-occupied West Bank.\n\nSeveral reconciliation bids have failed, but calls have grown since the Hamas October attack and nine-month war in Gaza, with violence also soaring in the West Bank where Fatah is based.\n\nChina hosted Fatah and Hamas in April but a meeting scheduled for June was postponed.\n\nChina has historically been sympathetic to the Palestinian cause and supportive of a two-state solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.\n\nChina has positioned itself as a more neutral actor on the Israel-Palestinian conflict than its rival the United States, advocating for a two-state solution while also maintaining good ties with Israel.\n\nPromotedListen to the latest songs, only on JioSaavn.com\n\nIt has sought to play a greater role in the Middle East in recent years, facilitating last year's historic rapprochement between Saudi Arabia and Iran.\n\n(Except for the headline, this story has not been edited by NDTV staff and is published {"uri": "8239501644", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-23", "time": "13:26:18", "dateTime": "2024-07-23T13:26:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-23T13:25:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://kayhanlife.com/news/world/palestinian-factions-agree-to-form-national-unity-govt-after-talks-in-china/", "title": "Palestinian Factions Agree to Form National Unity Govt, After Talks in China - KAYHAN LIFE", "body": "BEIJING/CAIRO, July 23 (Reuters) - Palestinian factions including rivals Hamas and Fatah agreed to end their divisions and form an interim national unity government during negotiations in China that ended on Tuesday, China's foreign ministry said.\n\nThe Beijing Declaration was signed at the closing ceremony of a reconciliation dialogue among 14 Palestinian factions held in China's capital from July 21-23, according to the readout.\n\nPrevious efforts by Egypt and other Arab countries to reconcile Hamas and Fatah have failed to end 17 years of power-sharing conflict that have weakened Palestinian political aspirations, and it remains to be seen whether this deal will survive the realities on the ground.\n\nThe meeting was held amid attempts by international mediators to reach a ceasefire deal for Gaza, with one of the sticking points being the \"day-after\" plan - how the Hamas-run enclave will be governed once the war that began on Oct. 7 ends.\n\nSenior Hamas official Hussam Badran said the most important point of the Beijing Declaration was to form a Palestinian national unity government to manage the affairs of Palestinians.\n\nPalestinian Leader Mahmoud Abbas Criticizes Khamenei for Backing Hamas\n\n\"This creates a formidable barrier against all regional and international interventions that seek to impose realities against our people's interests in managing Palestinian affairs post-war,\" Badran said.\n\nIsraeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has said his goal is to destroy the Iran-backed Hamas group and opposes it having any role in a post war Gaza administration.\n\n\"Instead of rejecting terrorism, (Fatah leader) Mahmoud Abbas embraces the murderers and rapists of Hamas, revealing his true face. In reality, this won't happen because Hamas' rule will be crushed, and Abbas will be watching Gaza from afar. Israel's security will remain solely in Israel's hands,\" Israeli Foreign Minister Israel Katz said on X.\n\nBadran said the national unity government would manage the affairs of Palestinians in Gaza and the West Bank, oversee reconstruction, and prepare conditions for elections.\n\nCurrently Hamas runs Gaza and Fatah forms the backbone of the Palestinian Authority, which has limited control in the Israeli-occupied West Bank. There has been no immediate comment from Fatah.\n\nDetails of the agreement did not set out a timeframe for forming a new government. In March, Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas, who heads Fatah, appointed a new government led by one of his close aides, Mohammad Mustafa.\n\nTWO-STATE SOLUTION\n\nNonetheless, the agreement marks a diplomatic coup for Beijing and its growing influence in the Middle East, after it brokered a breakthrough peace deal between longstanding regional foes Saudi Arabia and Iran last year.\n\n\"The core achievement is to make it clear that the Palestine Liberation Organization is the sole legitimate representative of the Palestinian people,\" Chinese foreign minister Wang Yi said during the closing ceremony, according to the readout.\n\n\"China sincerely hopes that the Palestinian factions will achieve Palestinian independence at an early date on the basis of internal reconciliation, and is willing to strengthen communication and coordination with relevant parties to jointly work to implement the Beijing Declaration reached today.\"\n\nThe most \"prominent highlight\" was the agreement on forming an interim national reconciliation government around the post-war governance of Gaza, Wang said, adding that the international community should support efforts to form an interim Palestinian government to control Gaza and the West Bank.\n\nHamas and Islamic Jihad are not members of the PLO, the Palestinians' highest decision-making body, but they demand that any unity deal includes holding an election for the PLO parliament to secure their inclusion. The Islamist groups are at odds with the current PLO over peace accords with Israel.\n\n\"This declaration comes at an important time as our people are facing a genocidal war, especially in the Gaza Strip,\" a statement quoted Badran as saying.\n\nRival factions Hamas and Fatah first met in Beijing in April to discuss reconciliation efforts to end around 17 years of disputes, the first time a Hamas delegation was publicly known to have visited China since the war in Gaza began.\n\nThe second round of talks, originally planned for last month, were delayed as both factions traded blame.\n\nThe long-feuding Palestinian factions have previously failed to heal their political disputes after Hamas fighters expelled Fatah from Gaza in a short war in 2007.\n\nChinese officials have ramped up advocacy for the Palestinians in international forums in recent months, calling for a larger-scale Israeli-Palestinian peace conference and a specific timetable to implement a two-state {"uri": "8239064141", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-23", "time": "08:57:26", "dateTime": "2024-07-23T08:57:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-23T08:56:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://www.newarab.com/news/hamas-announces-national-unity-deal-beijing-fatah", "title": "Hamas announces 'national unity' deal in Beijing with Fatah", "body": "Hamas announced on Tuesday it had signed an agreement in Beijing with other Palestinian organisations including rivals Fatah to work together for \"national unity\", with China describing it as a deal to rule Gaza together once the war ends.\n\nChinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi, who hosted senior Hamas official Musa Abu Marzouk, Fatah envoy Mahmoud al-Aloul and emissaries from 12 other Palestinian groups, said they had agreed to set up an \"interim national reconciliation government\" to govern post-war Gaza.\n\n\"Today we sign an agreement for national unity and we say that the path to completing this journey is national unity. We are committed to national unity and we call for it,\" Abu Marzouk said after meeting Wang and the other envoys.\n\nThe announcement comes more than nine months into a war sparked by Hamas's 7 October attack on southern Israel, which resulted in the deaths of 1,197 people, mostly civilians, according to an AFP tally based on Israeli figures.\n\nThe militants also seized 251 hostages, 116 of whom are still in Gaza, including 44 the Israeli military says are dead.\n\nIsrael's retaliatory military campaign in Gaza has killed 39,006 people, also mostly civilians, with a further 89,818 wounded, according to data from the health ministry in Gaza.\n\nThe relentless fighting has plunged Gaza into a severe humanitarian crisis.\n\nChina has sought to play a mediator role in the conflict, which has been rendered even more complex due to the intense rivalry between Hamas, which rules the Gaza Strip, and Fatah, which partially governs the Israeli occupied West Bank.\n\nIsrael has vowed to keep fighting until it destroys Hamas, and world powers including key Israeli backer the United States have scrambled to imagine scenarios for the governance of Gaza once the war ends.\n\nNeither Israel nor the United States would sanction any post-war plan that includes Hamas, which is proscribed as a terrorist organisation by Washington.\n\nWhile it is unclear whether the deal announced in Beijing on Tuesday can hold, it does indicate that the only world power that can engineer a rapprochement between the Palestinian rivals is China.\n\nAs Tuesday's meeting wrapped up in Beijing, Wang said the groups had committed to \"reconciliation\".\n\n\"The most prominent highlight is the agreement to form an interim national reconciliation government around the governance of post-war Gaza,\" Wang said after the factions signed the \"Beijing declaration\" in the Chinese capital.\n\n\"Reconciliation is an internal matter for the Palestinian factions, but at the same time, it cannot be achieved without the support of the international community,\" Wang said.\n\nFatah official Mahmoud al-Aloul thanked China for its \"unending support\" for the Palestinian cause.\n\n\"To China, you have our love, you have all our friendship, from all the Palestinian people,\" he said.\n\nNotably, he did not mention whether any agreement had been reached with Hamas and the other factions.\n\nAlso present at Tuesday's meeting were envoys from Egypt, Algeria and Russia, according to Wang.\n\nEgypt, which neighbours Israel and Gaza, is a key mediator in the conflict.\n\nAlgeria is a non-permanent member of the UN Security Council, and has drafted resolutions on the war.\n\nAnd while Western powers have sought to isolate Russia over its Ukraine invasion, China has maintained its strategic partnership with Moscow.\n\nChina, Wang said, was keen to \"play a constructive role in safeguarding peace and stability in the Middle East\".\n\nHe also called for a \"comprehensive, lasting and sustainable ceasefire\", as well as efforts to promote Palestinian self-governance and full recognition of a Palestinian state at the UN.\n\nHamas and Fatah have been bitter rivals since Hamas fighters ejected Fatah from the Gaza Strip after deadly clashes that followed Hamas's resounding victory in a 2006 election.\n\nFatah controls the Palestinian Authority, which has partial administrative control in the Israeli-occupied West Bank.\n\nSeveral reconciliation bids have failed, but calls have grown since the Hamas October attack and nine-month war in Gaza, with Israeli raids and settler violence against Palestinians also soaring in the West Bank where Fatah is based.\n\nChina hosted Fatah and Hamas in April but a meeting scheduled for June was postponed.\n\nChina has historically been sympathetic to the Palestinian cause and supportive of a two-state solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.\n\nChina has positioned itself as a more neutral actor on the Israel-Palestinian conflict than its rival the United States, advocating for a two-state solution while also maintaining good ties with Israel.\n\nAnd it has sought to play a greater role in the Middle East in recent years, facilitating last year's historic rapprochement between Saudi Arabia and Iran.", "source": {"uri": "newarab.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The New Arab"}, "authors": {"uri": "8239699046", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-23", "time": "15:26:29", "dateTime": "2024-07-23T15:26:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-23T15:25:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://exbulletin.com/politics/2800408/", "title": "Hamas, Fatah sign deal in Beijing ending division, China says - ExBulletin", "body": "Palestinian factions, including rivals Hamas and Fatah, have signed an agreement aimed at ending division and strengthening Palestinian unity in Beijing, China said Tuesday.\n\nThe announcement follows China-brokered reconciliation talks involving 14 Palestinian factions starting Sunday, according to China's foreign ministry, which come as Israel wages a war against the militant group Hamas in Gaza and Beijing seeks to portray itself as a potential peace broker in the conflict.\n\nChinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi said the agreement was dedicated to the great reconciliation and unity of the 14 factions.\n\nThe main result is that the PLO (Palestine Liberation Organization) is the sole legitimate representative of all the Palestinian people, Wang said, adding that an agreement has been reached on the post-war governance of Gaza and the establishment of an interim government of national reconciliation.\n\nWang's remarks did not make it clear what role Hamas, which is not part of the PLO, would play in such a deal, or what the immediate impact of such a deal would be. The talks came as the future governance of the Palestinian territories remains uncertain following Israel's repeated promise to eradicate Hamas in response to the Oct. 7 terror attack on its territory.\n\nThe PLO is a coalition of parties that signed a peace treaty with Israel in 1993 and formed a new government within the Palestinian Authority (PA).\n\nFatah dominates both the PLO and the PA, the interim Palestinian government established in the Israeli-occupied West Bank after the signing of the 1993 Oslo Accords. Hamas was not a party to the accords and does not recognize Israel.\n\nMustafa Barghouti, chairman of the Palestinian National Initiative, who was present at the Beijing talks, said all parties had agreed to join the PLO and that the organization was the sole legitimate representative of the Palestinians.\n\nThere is a long history of bitter enmity between Hamas and Fatah. The two sides have repeatedly tried to reach an agreement to unite the two separate Palestinian territories under a single governance structure, with the 2017 deal quickly turning violent.\n\nThe Palestinian Authority exercised administrative control over Gaza until 2007, after Hamas won the 2006 legislative elections in the occupied territories and expelled it from the Gaza Strip. Since then, Hamas has ruled Gaza and the Palestinian Authority has governed parts of the West Bank.\n\nHamas and Fatah signed a reconciliation deal in Cairo in October 2017, under pressure from Arab states led by Egypt. Under the deal, a new unity government was to take administrative control of Gaza two months later, ending a decade of rivalry that began when Hamas violently expelled the Palestinian Authority from Gaza in 2007.\n\nBut the deal's ambitions were quickly dashed. When Palestinian Authority Prime Minister Rami Hamdallah visited Gaza in March 2018, he was the target of an assassination attempt when a bomb exploded near his convoy. Hamdallah's Fatah party immediately blamed Hamas for the attack.\n\nBarghouti said the latest attempt at reconciliation between Palestinian factions went much further than previous efforts and included specific steps toward forming a consensus government.\n\nThe war in Gaza, he told CNN, has pushed factions to unite in a common front against the Israeli occupation.\n\nThere is a very clear sense that what Israel is doing is a threat to everyone, he said. And so in that sense, the sense of unity to confront the Israeli side is very clear here.\n\nA new government would ensure the unity of the occupied West Bank and Gaza, governing the two territories after the war and effectively blocking Israeli efforts to maintain its occupation of Gaza, he said.\n\nMost Palestinians, however, would take the news of reconciliation with the usual caution and pessimism, said Tahani Mustafa, a senior Palestine analyst at the International Crisis Group, a Brussels-based think tank.\n\nThe main issues that have stood in the way of reconciliation in the past have not been addressed, she told CNN. It is highly unlikely that anything substantial will come of it, especially since the biggest obstacle so far has been Mahmoud Abbas (president of the Palestinian Authority and leader of Fatah) and his absolute unwillingness to give up his monopoly on power in any way.\n\nHamas is not opposed to the PLO but demands equal representation within the organization, she added. Abbas has been reluctant to accept this because it would mean Fatah would lose its hegemony over the last Palestinian political institution it controls.\n\nAt a press conference in Beijing on Tuesday, Hamas delegation representative Mousa Abu Marzook said they had reached an agreement to complete a reconciliation process, while using Beijing's platform to defend the group's October 7 attack on Israel.\n\n\"We are at a historic turning point. Our people are rising up in their struggle efforts,\" Abu Marzook said, according to a translation provided by the Chinese Foreign Ministry, adding that the October 7 operation had changed a lot in both the international and regional landscape.\n\nBeijing has not explicitly condemned Hamas for its October 7 attack on Israel.\n\nTuesday's deal follows a previous round of negotiations between Hamas and Fatah brokered by Beijing in April.\n\nSince the start of the Gaza war, China, which has sought to strengthen its influence and ties in the Middle East in recent years, has presented itself as a leading voice for countries in the Global South denouncing Israel's war in the enclave and calling for the creation of a Palestinian state.\n\nIn May, Chinese leader Xi Jinping called for an international peace conference during his meetings with Arab leaders and also dispatched a special envoy to the Middle East to meet with diplomats and officials.\n\nObservers have questioned the extent of Beijing's geopolitical influence in a region where the United States has long been a dominant power, but China surprised many last March when it played a role as a broker in a rapprochement between longtime rivals Saudi Arabia and Iran.\n\nThese efforts have been widely seen as part of Beijing's push to position itself as a geopolitical heavyweight with a different worldview from the United States.\n\nTuesday's deal also came as Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is in the United States for a highly anticipated visit during which he will meet with senior U.S. officials and address Congress.\n\nIsrael launched its military operations in Gaza after the October 7 Hamas attack, which left more than 1,100 dead and about 250 kidnapped. About 39,000 Palestinians have died in the conflict, which has triggered a massive humanitarian crisis and widespread destruction.", "source": {"uri": "exbulletin.com", "dataType": "news", "title": Israel's retaliatory campaign in Gaza has killed more than 39,000 people, according to Gaza officials\n\nWar-torn Palestinians search for wood, paper and cardboard in rubble of collapsed buildings amid the ongoing Israeli attacks as hunger and fuel crisis deepens in the southern Gaza Strip city of Khan Yunis, on Monday\n\nIsrael has vowed to keep fighting until it destroys Hamas, and world powers have scrambled to imagine scenarios for the governance of Gaza once the war ends.\n\nNeither Israel nor the US would sanction any post-war plan that includes Hamas, which is proscribed as a terrorist organisation by Washington.\n\nWhile it is unclear whether the deal announced in Beijing on Tuesday can hold, it does indicate that the only world power that can engineer a rapprochement between the Palestinian rivals is China.\n\nAs Tuesday's meeting wrapped up in Beijing, Wang said the groups had committed to 'reconciliation'.\n\n'The most prominent highlight is the agreement to form an interim national reconciliation government around the governance of post-war Gaza,' Wang said after the factions signed the 'Beijing declaration' in the Chinese capital.\n\nRead More Israel's presence in Palestinian territories is unlawful, UN's top court rules\n\n'Reconciliation is an internal matter for the Palestinian factions, but at the same time, it cannot be achieved without the support of the international community,' Wang said.\n\nFatah official Mahmoud al-Aloul thanked China for its 'unending support' for the Palestinian cause.\n\n'To China, you have our love, you have all our friendship, from all the Palestinian people,' he said.\n\nNotably, he did not mention whether any agreement had been reached with Hamas and the other factions.\n\nAlso present at Tuesday's meeting were envoys from Egypt, Algeria and Russia, according to Wang.\n\nEgypt, which neighbours Israel and Gaza, is a key mediator in the conflict.\n\nAlgeria is a non-permanent member of the UN Security Council, and has drafted resolutions on the war.\n\nAnd while Western powers have sought to isolate Russia over its Ukraine invasion, China has maintained its strategic partnership with Moscow.\n\nChina, Wang said, was keen to 'play a constructive role in safeguarding peace and stability in the Middle East'.\n\nice Chairman of the Central Committee of Palestinian organisation and the Israel-Palestinian conflict than its rival the United States, advocating for a two-state solution\n\nHe also called for a 'comprehensive, lasting and sustainable ceasefire', as well as efforts to {"uri": "8239078670", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-23", "time": "09:07:27", "dateTime": "2024-07-23T09:07:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-23T09:06:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.lemonde.fr/en/international/article/2024/07/23/hamas-announces-national-unity-deal-with-other-key-palestinian-organizations_6695135_4.html", "title": "Hamas announces 'national unity' deal with other key Palestinian organizations", "body": "Hamas announced Tuesday, July 23, it had signed an agreement in Beijing with other Palestinian organizations including rivals Fatah to work together for \"national unity,\" with China describing it as a deal to rule Gaza together once the war ends.\n\nChinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi, who hosted senior Hamas official Musa Abu Marzuk, Fatah envoy Mahmud al-Aloul and emissaries from 12 other Palestinian groups, said they had agreed to set up an \"interim national reconciliation government\" to govern post-war Gaza. \"Today we sign an agreement for national unity and we say that the path to completing this journey is national unity. We are committed to national unity and we call for it,\" Abu Marzuk said after meeting Wang and the other envoys.\n\nChina has sought to play a mediator role in the conflict, which has been rendered even more complex due to the intense rivalry between Hamas, which rules the Gaza Strip, and Fatah, which partially governs the occupied West Bank. While it is unclear whether the deal announced in Beijing on Tuesday can hold, it does indicate that the only world power that can engineer a rapprochement between the Palestinian rivals is China.\n\nAs Tuesday's meeting wrapped up in Beijing, Wang said the groups had committed to \"reconciliation.\" \"The most prominent highlight is the agreement to form an interim national reconciliation government around the governance of post-war Gaza,\" Wang said after the factions signed the \"Beijing declaration\" in the Chinese capital. \"Reconciliation is an internal matter for the Palestinian factions, but at the same time, it cannot be achieved without the support of the international community,\" Wang said.\n\nFatah official Mahmoud al-Aloul thanked China for its \"unending support\" for the Palestinian cause. \"To China, you have our love, you have all our friendship, from all the Palestinian people,\" he said. Notably, he did not mention whether any agreement had been reached with Hamas and the other factions.\n\nAlso present at Tuesday's meeting were envoys from Egypt, Algeria and Russia, according to Wang. Egypt, which neighbors Israel and Gaza, is a key mediator in the conflict. Algeria is a non-permanent member of the UN Security Council and has drafted resolutions on the war. And while Western powers have sought to isolate Russia over its Ukraine invasion, China has maintained its strategic partnership with Moscow.\n\nChina, Wang said, was keen to \"play a constructive role in safeguarding peace and stability in the Middle East.\" He also called for a \"comprehensive, lasting and sustainable ceasefire\", as well as efforts to promote Palestinian self-governance and full recognition of a Palestinian state at the UN.\n\nHamas and Fatah have been bitter rivals since Hamas fighters ejected Fatah from the Gaza Strip after deadly clashes that followed Hamas's resounding victory in a 2006 election. Fatah controls the Palestinian Authority, which has partial administrative control in the Israeli-occupied West Bank.\n\nSeveral reconciliation bids have failed, but calls have grown since the Hamas October attack and nine-month war in Gaza, with violence also soaring in the West Bank where Fatah is based. China hosted Fatah and Hamas in April but a meeting scheduled for June was postponed. China has historically been sympathetic to the Palestinian cause and supportive of a two-state solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.\n\nChina has positioned itself as a more neutral actor on the Israel-Palestinian conflict than its rival the United States, advocating for a two-state solution while also maintaining good ties with Israel. And it has sought to play a greater role in the Middle East in recent years, facilitating last year's historic rapprochement between Saudi Arabia and Iran.", "source": {"uri": "lemonde.fr", {"uri": "2024-07-430628873", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-23", "time": "08:56:36", "dateTime": "2024-07-23T08:56:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-23T00:00:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.breakingnews.ie/world/hamas-and-fatah-sign-deal-to-end-years-long-rift-after-talks-in-china-1653058.html", "title": "Hamas and Fatah sign deal to end years-long rift after talks in China", "body": "Palestinian factions Hamas and Fatah have signed a declaration in Beijing ending a years-long rift, Chinese state media said.\n\nThe declaration by the two heavyweights of Palestinian politics -- and other smaller Palestinian groups -- to form a unity government for the Palestinian territories is the result of the latest in a series of talks meant to unite the sides.\n\nBut previous declarations have failed, including a similar deal in 2011, casting doubt over whether the China-sponsored negotiations might actually lead to a resolution. It also comes as Israel and Hamas are weighing an internationally backed ceasefire proposal that would wind down the nine-month war and free dozens of Israeli hostages held by Hamas.\n\nStill, the future of Gaza is undecided, with Israel vehemently opposed to any role by Hamas in governing Gaza. It has also rejected calls from the United States for the Fatah-dominated Palestinian Authority to run Gaza after the war ends.\n\nThe lack of a post-war vision for running the Gaza Strip has complicated ceasefire negotiations.\n\nSince the current war broke out in Gaza almost 10 months ago, Hamas officials have said that the party does not want to return to ruling Gaza as it did before the conflict.\n\nThe group has called for the formation of a government of technocrats to be agreed upon by the various Palestinian factions, which would prepare the way for elections for both Gaza and the West Bank, with the intention of forming a unified government.\n\nHamas and Fatah signed the Beijing Declaration on \"ending division and strengthening Palestinian unity\", according to state broadcaster CCTV.\n\nThe two rival Palestinian groups, along with 12 other political factions, met Chinese foreign minister Wang Yi on Tuesday, concluding talks that started on Sunday.\n\nA joint statement issued after the most recent talks in Beijing gave no details on how or when the government would be formed, saying only that it would be done \"by agreement among the factions\".\n\nAccording to the joint statement, the two groups are committed to the creation of a Palestinian state on lands Israel captured in the 1967 Mideast war.\n\nWhile the groups have said they would work together many times before and failed, the signing of the declaration coincides with US Secretary of State Antony Blinken saying that a ceasefire between Israel and Hamas appears within sight.\n\nHamas routed Fatah forces in Gaza in a violent takeover of the territory in 2007.\n\nUnity efforts have been wrecked by the factions' own bitter rivalry over power and the West's refusal to accept any government that includes Hamas unless it expressly recognises Israel.", "source": {"uri": "breakingnews.ie", "dataType": "news", "title": "Breaking News.ie"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8239586991", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-23", "time": "14:14:42", "dateTime": "2024-07-23T14:14:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-23T14:12:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/pa/article-13663643/Hamas-Fatah-sign-declaration-form-future-government-war-rages-Gaza.html", "title": "Hamas and Fatah sign declaration to form future government as war...", "body": "Palestinian factions Hamas and Fatah have signed a declaration vowing to form a government together.\n\nThe event, hosted by China, is the latest attempt at resolving the years-long rivalry between the two groups.\n\nBoth sides said the accord, which provided no guarantees or timeline, was only an initial step.\n\nPrevious such declarations have failed, raising doubt over whether the China-sponsored negotiations might lead to a resolution between Hamas, which has ruled the Gaza Strip for the past 17 years, and Fatah, the main force in the US-backed Palestinian Authority that administers parts of the occupied West Bank.\n\nPalestinians displaced by the Israeli air and ground offensive on the Gaza Strip flee from parts of Khan Younis (Abdel Kareem Hana/AP)\n\nIsrael swiftly denounced the agreement while the US and other Western countries have refused to accept any Palestinian government that includes Hamas unless it expressly recognises Israel -- a factor that has helped wreck past unity attempts, along with the factions' own competition for power.\n\nChinese state broadcaster CCTV announced that the two sides and other, smaller Palestinian factions signed the Beijing Declaration on \"ending division and strengthening Palestinian unity\", pledging to form a unity government for the Palestinian territories.\n\nThe agreement offered only broad outlines of how they would work together.\n\n\"There is an opportunity ... but it is not big, because it lacks a specific timetable for implementation,\" said Hani Al-Masry, an expert on Palestinian reconciliation affairs.\n\nChina\u00b4s Foreign Minister hosted the event as the nation attempts to grow its role in Middle East diplomacy (Pedro Pardo/Pool Photo via AP)\n\nThe declaration comes at a sensitive time, as the war in Gaza rages on into its 10th month and as Israel and Hamas are weighing an internationally backed ceasefire proposal that would wind down the war and free dozens of Israeli hostages held by Hamas.\n\nOne of the thorniest issues is the question of who will run Gaza after the war -- and the unity efforts are in part motivated by Palestinians' desire to offer a scenario for post-war rule.\n\nBut Israel vehemently opposes any role for Hamas, which it has vowed to destroy after its October 7 attack on southern Israel.\n\nIt also has rejected US calls for the Palestinian Authority to govern Gaza after the fighting ends, though it has not presented a cohesive post-war vision of its own.\n\nPalestinian President Mahmoud Abbas's Fatah has been deeply reluctant to share power with its long-time rival.\n\nHamas won Palestinian parliamentary elections in 2006. The following year, amid escalating tensions, Hamas routed forces loyal to Abbas in Gaza. It has ruled the impoverished coastal enclave ever since.\n\nThe accord provided no guarantees or timelines but marked the initial step forward for two rival groups (Pedro Pardo/Pool Photo via AP)\n\nDuring the current war, Hamas officials have said the group does not want to return to ruling Gaza and advocates forming a government of technocrats to be agreed upon by the various Palestinian factions.\n\nThat government would then prepare for elections in Gaza and the West Bank, with the intention of forming a unified government.\n\nReacting to the announcement out of China, Israel's foreign minister said no joint governance between Hamas and Fatah in Gaza will take place \"because Hamas' rule will be crushed\".\n\nThe agreement also underscored China's attempts to have a growing role in Middle East diplomacy, after its success in mediating the restoration of relations between Saudi Arabia and Iran.\n\n\"To be sure, China is still in the process of trying to earn credibility as a global mediator,\" said James Char, a research fellow at the Institute of Defence and Strategic Studies at Nanyang Technological University in Singapore.\n\nOfficials from Fatah, Hamas and 12 other factions met with Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi, concluding talks that started Sunday, according to a post on social media platform Weibo from Chinese TV network CGTN.\n\nThe two rival groups have said that they are committed to the creation of a Palestinian state on lands captured by Israel in the 1960s (Abdel Kareem Hana/AP)\n\nThe Palestinian factions issued a joint statement announcing the deal but giving no details on how or when the government would be formed, saying only that it would be done \"by agreement among the factions\".\n\nIt said they promised to follow up on previous reconciliation agreements signed in 2011 and 2022.\n\nIn the statement, all the factions, including Hamas, said they were committed to the creation of a Palestinian state on lands Israel captured in the 1967 Mideast war.\n\nHamas, whose original charter directly called for Israel's destruction, has said it would accept a Palestinian state based on the pre-1967 war borders but refuses to officially recognise Israel.\n\nThe Palestinian Authority, meanwhile, has recognised Israel and works within the framework of peace deals signed in the early 1990s.\n\nThose deals were supposed to lead to an eventual state in the West Bank and Gaza, but talks have been defunct for years, leaving it in charge of only isolated West Bank enclaves.\n\nA ceasefire proposal is still in the works as Israel and Hamas try to come to an agreement to end the war (AP Photo/Abdel Kareem Hana)\n\nMany Palestinians view the authority as corrupt, out of touch and a subcontractor for Israel because of their joint security co-ordination.\n\nThe unity announcement is based on widening the membership of the Fatah-led Palestine Liberation Organisation (PLO), including Hamas, said Jamal Nazzal, a Fatah spokesperson.\n\n\"It's a long way ahead, and most of it will be implemented after a possible ceasefire,\" he added.\n\nHamas members have never been part of the PLO, the umbrella group of Palestinian factions that undergirds the Palestinian Authority.\n\nHusam Badran, a Hamas political official based in Qatar, called the agreement a further \"positive step towards achieving Palestinian national unity\".\n\nUS President Joe Biden's administration envisions a revamped Palestinian Authority ruling post-war Gaza and has sought reforms that might make it a viable presence in the war-ravaged territory. However, Israel rejected that idea.\n\nThe Palestinian Islamic Jihad, a smaller militant group allied with Hamas, issued a statement after the talks saying it still \"rejects any formula that includes recognition of Israel explicitly or implicitly\" and that it had \"demanded the withdrawal of the Palestine Liberation Organisation's recognition of Israel\".", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", {"uri": "2024-07-430690658", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-23", "time": "09:50:43", "dateTime": "2024-07-23T09:50:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-23T09:34:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.channel3000.com/news/national-and-world-news/israel-conflict/hamas-and-fatah-sign-declaration-in-beijing-on-ending-yearslong-rift-as-war-rages-in/article_7f840ad2-0228-5726-bf7d-6cd53d27e235.html", "title": "Hamas and Fatah sign declaration in Beijing on ending yearslong rift as war rages in Gaza", "body": "By JACK JEFFERY, TIA GOLDENBERG and HUIZHONG WU - Associated Press\n\nRAMALLAH, West Bank (AP) -- Palestinian factions Hamas and Fatah signed a declaration in Beijing on ending a yearslong rift, Chinese state media said Tuesday, taking a step toward potentially resolving the deep divide between the sides as the war in Gaza rages on.\n\nThe declaration by the two heavyweights of Palestinian politics -- and other smaller Palestinian groups -- to form a unity government for the Palestinian territories is the result of the latest in a series of talks meant to unite the sides.\n\nBut previous declarations have failed, including a similar deal in 2011, casting doubt over whether the China-sponsored negotiations might actually lead to a resolution. It also comes as Israel and Hamas are weighing an internationally backed cease-fire proposal that would wind down the nine-month war and free dozens of Israeli hostages held by Hamas.\n\nStill, the future of Gaza is undecided, with Israel vehemently opposed to any role by Hamas in governing Gaza. It has also rejected calls from the United States for the Fatah-dominated Palestinian Authority to run Gaza after the war ends. The lack of a postwar vision for running the Gaza Strip has complicated negotiations over a cease-fire.\n\nSince the current war broke out in Gaza almost 10 months ago, Hamas officials have said that the party does not want to return to ruling Gaza as it did before the conflict, and the group has called for formation of a government of technocrats to be agreed upon by the various Palestinian factions, which would prepare the way for elections for both Gaza and the West Bank, with the intention of forming a unified government.\n\nThe two groups signed the Beijing Declaration on \"ending division and strengthening Palestinian unity,\" according to state broadcaster CCTV.\n\nIsrael's Foreign Minister, Israel Katz, swiftly rejected the agreement Tuesday, stating that no joint governance between Hamas and Fatah in Gaza will take place \"because Hamas's rule will be crushed.\"\n\nThe two rival Palestinian groups, along with 12 other political factions, met with Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi, concluding talks that started Sunday, according to a post on social media platform Weibo from Chinese TV network CGTN.\n\nThe agreement also underscores China's growing role in Middle East diplomacy, with success in the restoration of relations between Saudi Arabia and Iran.\n\n\"But to be sure, China is still the process of trying to earn credibility as a global mediator,\" said James Char, a research fellow at the Institute of Defence and Strategic Studies at Nanyang Technological University in Singapore.\n\nA joint statement issued after the most recent talks in Beijing gave no details on how or when the government would be formed, saying only that it would be done \"by agreement among the factions.\" According to the joint statement, the two groups are committed to the creation of a Palestinian state on lands Israel captured in the 1967 Mideast war.\n\nThe deal does not appear to bridge the two group's diverging position on Israel. Hamas previously said it would accept a state based on 1967 borders, while also refusing to officially recognize Israel. The Fatah-dominated Palestinian Authority, meanwhile, abides by interim peace agreements with Israel signed in the early 1990s.\n\nThe agreement signed by the Palestinian factions promised to follow up on previous reconciliation agreements signed in both 2011 and 2022.\n\n\"The understanding in China is based on widening the scope of the membership on the PLO (Palestine Liberation Organization) to include other factions who have not joined it\" including Hamas, said Jamal Nazzal, a Fatah spokesperson.\n\n\"It's a long way ahead, and most of it will be implemented after a possible cease-fire,\" he added.\n\nFatah and Hamas have been rivals since Hamas violently routed forces loyal to Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas' Fatah in Gaza in 2007, taking over the impoverished coastal enclave. The Fatah-dominated Palestinian Authority, headed by Abbas, administers parts of the occupied West Bank. It is widely viewed by the Palestinian public as corrupt, out of touch, and a subcontractor for Israel because of their joint security coordination.\n\nHamas members have never been part of PLO, the Palestinian government body responsible for international affairs. In a statement, Husam Badran, a Hamas political official based in Qatar, praised the agreement, describing it as a further \"positive step towards achieving Palestinian national unity.\"\n\nBut Tuesday's deal doesn't have a hard timeline.\n\n\"There is an opportunity ... but it is not big, because it lacks a specific timetable for implementation,\" said Hani Al-Masry, an expert on Palestinian reconciliation affairs.\n\nRepeated attempts at mending the rift have failed, wrecked by the factions' own bitter rivalry over power and the West's refusal to accept any government that includes Hamas unless it expressly recognizes Israel.\n\nUnited States President Joe Biden's administration envisions a revamped Palestinian Authority to rule postwar Gaza and has sought a series of reforms that might make it a viable presence in the war-ravaged territory. Israel rejected that idea, but has not put forward a credible alternative for who will govern Gaza.\n\nThe Palestinian Islamic Jihad, a smaller militant group allied with Hamas, issued a statement Tuesday after the talks saying that it still \"rejects any formula that includes recognition of Israel explicitly or implicitly\" and that it had \"demanded the withdrawal of the Palestine Liberation Organization's recognition of Israel.\"\n\nGoldenberg reported from Tel Aviv, Israel; Wu reported from Bangkok. Abby Sewell contributed to this report from Beirut.\n\nCOPYRIGHT 2024 BY CHANNEL 3000. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED.
