{"uri": "8239209373", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-23", "time": "10:27:03", "dateTime": "2024-07-23T10:27:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-23T10:26:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://sonna.so/en/palestinian-factions-signed-the-beijing-declaration-on-ending-divisions-and-strengthening-palestinian-national-unity-in-beijing/", "title": "Palestinian factions signed the Beijing Declaration on Ending Divisions and Strengthening Palestinian National Unity in Beijing", "body": "On July 23, 2024, Wang Yi, member of the Political Bureau of the CPC Central Committee and Minister of Foreign Affairs, attended the closing ceremony of the Dialogue on Reconciliation among Palestinian factions in Beijing, witnessing the signing of the Beijing Declaration on Ending Secession and Strengthening Palestinian Unity by 14 Palestinian factions.\n\nIn his speech, Wang Yi said that since the beginning of the new era, President Xi Jinping has repeatedly put forward proposals and proposals for resolving the Palestinian issue, and has contributed Chinese wisdom and solutions to the settlement of the Palestinian issue. This is an important historic moment in the cause of Palestinian liberation, when 14 Palestinian factions gather in Beijing in the spirit of national righteousness. The Chinese side appreciates the efforts made by all parties to reconcile and congratulates the successful Beijing dialogue and the signing of the Beijing Declaration.\n\nWang Yi pointed out that only when all Palestinian factions speak with one voice can the voice of justice be louder, and only by joining hands and advancing side by side can the cause of national liberation succeed. The most important consensus reached by the Palestinian factions at the Beijing dialogue is to achieve great reconciliation and unity among the 14 factions, the core result is to make it clear that the PLO is the sole legitimate representative of all the Palestinian people, the most prominent highlight is the agreement to form an interim national reconciliation government around the post-war governance of Gaza, and the strongest call is to realize the true independent state of Palestine in accordance with the relevant United Nations resolutions. The key to the process of internal reconciliation among the Palestinian factions is to strengthen confidence, grasp the direction and proceed in an orderly and gradual manner. Only by continuously building consensus and putting it into practice can the reconciliation process become more solid and more united. Reconciliation is an internal affair for all Palestinian factions, and it cannot be separated from the support of the international community. On the road to promoting reconciliation, China and the vast number of Arab and Islamic countries share the same direction and goal.\n\nWang Yi said that the Palestinian issue is the core of the Middle East issue. China has never had any selfish interests on the question of Palestine, and was one of the first countries to recognize the Palestine Liberation Organization and the State of Palestine. What we value is morality, and what we advocate is justice. At present, the conflict in Gaza is still prolonged, the spillover impact is spreading, and the regional conflict resonates at multiple points. In order to get out of the current conflict, China proposes a \"three-step approach\":\n\nThe first step is to promote a comprehensive, durable and sustainable ceasefire in the Gaza Strip as soon as possible and to ensure humanitarian assistance and access. The international community should further unite on the issue of a ceasefire and an end to hostilities.\n\nThe second step is to uphold the principle of \"Palestinians governing Pakistan\" and work together to promote post-war governance in Gaza. Gaza is an inseparable and important part of Palestine, and the urgent need to start post-war reconstruction as soon as possible has become an urgent issue in the next phase. The international community should support the Palestinian factions in forming an interim Government of National Consensus to exercise effective control over Gaza Jordan and the West Bank.\n\nThe third step is to promote Palestine as a full Member of the United Nations and to begin the implementation of the two-State solution. The convening of a larger, more authoritative and more effective international peace conference should be supported, and a timetable and road map should be drawn up in this regard.\n\nA ceasefire and humanitarian relief are imperative. \"Palestinians governing Pakistan\" is the basic principle of Gaza's post-war reconstruction. The two-state solution is the fundamental way forward. The international community should support the parties concerned in implementing the \"three-step approach\" in a serious manner.\n\nWang Yi said that the realization of internal reconciliation in Palestine will bring hope and a future to the Palestinian people, and is also an important step in promoting the settlement of the Palestinian issue and achieving peace and stability in the Middle East. China sincerely hopes that all Palestinian factions will achieve an independent Palestinian state on the basis of internal reconciliation at an early date, and is ready to strengthen communication and coordination with all parties concerned and make joint efforts to implement the Beijing Declaration reached today.\n\nAlul, head of the Fatah delegation, and Moussa, head of the Hamas delegation, delivered speeches on behalf of all Palestinian factions, emphasizing that China has a special and important position in the minds of the Palestinian people, and sincerely thanked President Xi Jinping and China for their long-term unwavering support and selfless assistance to Palestine. We highly appreciate China's commitment as a major country and uphold justice and justice for Palestine in the international community, and express our deep gratitude to China for its strong support for intra-Palestinian reconciliation and dialogue.\n\nRepresentatives of 14 major Palestinian factions, as well as envoys or representatives of Egypt, Algeria, Saudi Arabia, Qatar, Jordan, Syria, Lebanon, Russia and Turkey attended the closing ceremony.", "source": {"uri": "sonna.so", "dataType": "news", "title": "Wakaaladda Wararka Soomaaliyeed"}, "authors": [{"uri": "khadar_aweys@sonna.so", {"uri": "8239283399", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-23", "time": "11:11:25", "dateTime": "2024-07-23T11:11:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-23T11:10:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://www.winnipegfreepress.com/breakingnews/2024/07/23/israel-hamas-war-latest-netanyahu-signals-cease-fire-deal-could-be-shaping-up-as-deaths-top-39000", "title": "Israel-Hamas war latest: Netanyahu signals cease-fire deal could be shaping up as deaths top 39,000", "body": "I agree to the Terms and Conditions, Cookie and Privacy Policies, and CASL agreement.\n\nIsraeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has signaled that a cease-fire deal that would free dozens of hostages from captivity in Gaza could be taking shape. Netanyahu is in Washington, where he was to meet with President Joe Biden and Vice President Kamala Harris.\n\nThe Israeli military ordered the evacuation of part of a crowded area in the Gaza Strip it had designated a humanitarian zone, while the Health Ministry in Gaza says over 39,000 Palestinians have now been killed in the nine-month war.\n\nEgypt, Qatar and the United States are pushing Israel and Hamas toward a phased deal that would stop the fighting and free the remaining hostages. Netanyahu's office has said a negotiating team will be sent to continue talks Thursday.\n\nIn China, Palestinian factions Hamas and Fatah signed a declaration on forming a unity government and ending a yearslong rift. But previous declarations have failed, including a similar deal in 2011, casting doubt over whether the China-sponsored negotiations might actually lead to a resolution.\n\nHere's the latest:\n\nIsraeli forces raid a Palestinian city in the West Bank, killing at least 3 militants\n\nJERUSALEM -- Israeli forces raided a Palestinian city in the occupied West Bank and killed three militants, the military and Hamas said Tuesday. The Palestinian Health Ministry said a woman was also killed.\n\nThe military said a drone struck militants in the area of the northern West Bank city of Tulkarem overnight into Tuesday, killing Ashraf Nafa, who the military said was a local senior Hamas operative. It said another alleged militant, Mohammed Awad, was also killed in the raid, and said both had been behind attacks on Israeli soldiers. The Israeli military statement did not mention the woman killed.\n\nHamas identified Nafa as a member and said two other militants with the Al Aqsa Martyrs Brigades, including Awad, were also killed. The woman's identity was not immediately clear.\n\nFor several years, the Israeli military has been carrying out near nightly raids in the West Bank that intensified when the war in Gaza erupted. The Palestinian Health Ministry says more than 500 Palestinians have been killed in the ensuing violence, many of them in clashes with Israeli soldiers but others while throwing stones or protesting. People not involved in confrontations have also been killed.\n\nPalestinian attacks against Israelis have been on the rise in the territory.\n\nA top WHO official is worried about possible polio and other disease outbreaks in Gaza\n\nGENEVA -- A top World Health Organization official in Palestinian areas said Tuesday he's \"extremely worried\" about polio and other outbreaks of communicable diseases in Gaza after traces of the virus turned up in sewage samples in the territory.\n\nDr. Ayadil Saparbekov, team lead for health emergencies at WHO in the occupied Palestinian territory, said test results and a risk assessment were expected this week about how people and medical officials should respond to a possible outbreak.\n\nThere have been no confirmed human cases of polio in Gaza, but six of seven sewage samples tested positive for vaccine-derived polio virus, he said. That means that one or more people who got a polio vaccine jab have shed the virus in the environment.\n\n\"I am extremely worried about an outbreak happening in Gaza. And this is not only polio -- the different outbreaks of the communicable diseases that may happen,\" he told a United Nations briefing in Geneva by video, alluding to a hepatitis outbreak there in 2023.\n\nSaparbekov said lack of water, sanitation, and access to health care could lead to more people dying of communicable diseases than from injury related conditions.\n\nRolando Gomez, a United Nations spokesperson in Geneva, said Israel \"as the occupying power\" has a responsibility \"to ensure assistance reaches those in need in Gaza\" and to \"create an enabling environment for the U.N. and our partners to operate.\"\n\nIsrael has announced plans to vaccinate its soldiers operating in Gaza against polio.\n\nPalestinian factions sign a declaration in the latest attempt to clear the way for a unity government as the war in Gaza rages on\n\nRAMALLAH, West Bank -- Palestinian factions Hamas and Fatah signed a declaration in Beijing on ending a yearslong rift, Chinese state state broadcaster CCTV said Tuesday, taking a step toward potentially resolving the deep divide between the sides as the war in Gaza rages on.\n\nThe declaration by the two heavyweights of Palestinian politics -- and other smaller Palestinian groups -- to form a unity government for the Palestinian territories is the result of the latest in a series of talks meant to unite the sides.\n\nBut previous declarations have failed, including a similar deal in 2011, casting doubt over whether the China-sponsored negotiations might actually lead to a resolution. It also comes as Israel and Hamas are weighing an internationally backed cease-fire proposal that would wind down the nine-month war and free dozens of Israeli hostages held by Hamas.\n\nStill, the future of Gaza is undecided, with Israel vehemently opposed to any role by Hamas in governing Gaza. It has also rejected calls from the United States for the Fatah-dominated Palestinian Authority to run Gaza after the war ends. The lack of a postwar vision for running the Gaza Strip has complicated negotiations over a cease-fire.\n\nSince the current war broke out in Gaza almost 10 months ago, Hamas officials have said that the party does not want to return to ruling Gaza as it did before the conflict, and the group has called for formation of a government of technocrats to be agreed upon by the various Palestinian factions, which would prepare the way for elections for both Gaza and the West Bank, with the intention of forming a unified government.\n\nConditions for a cease-fire deal that would release hostages from captivity in Gaza are 'ripening,' Israel's Netanyahu says\n\nTEL AVIV, Israel -- Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has signaled that a cease-fire deal that would free dozens of hostages from captivity in Gaza could be taking shape.\n\nIn a meeting late Monday in Washington with families of hostages, Netanyahu said the conditions to bring the captives back were \"ripening,\" according to a statement from his office. He said that was happening because of the fierce military pressure Israel was putting on Hamas.\n\nHe gave no further details on the deal's progress.\n\nFor weeks, Israel and Hamas have been weighing a United States-backed cease-fire deal that would bring a halt to the nine-month war and free the roughly 120 hostages taken by Hamas during its Oct. 7 attack. About a third of the hostages are said to be dead, and Israel's military announced Monday that two more died in captivity.\n\nNetanyahu faces intense pressure from a broad swath of Israelis to agree to the deal. He has vowed to defeat Hamas before stopping the war, a term that has been a main sticking point throughout the negotiations.\n\nThe families of hostages had demanded that Netanyahu nail down a deal before flying to Washington, where he will address Congress and is expected to meet President Joe Biden.\n\nBill labeling UN Palestinian aid agency as a 'terror group' moves forward in Israel's parliament\n\nJERUSALEM, Israel -- An Israeli parliamentary bill that seeks to label the main provider of aid for Palestinians in Gaza a terrorist group is moving ahead.\n\nLegislators voted 50-10 in favor of the bill in a preliminary vote in Israel's parliament Monday. The bill requires two more votes before becoming law.\n\nThe bill is the product of increasingly tense relations between Israel and the United Nations agency for Palestinian refugees, known as UNRWA. Israel has accused the agency of militant links, claiming that hundreds of its employees are members of militant groups, including some who allegedly participated in Hamas' Oct. 7 attacks on southern Israel. Those accusations led to a global cascade of funding cuts to the agency.\n\nUNRWA employs thousands of workers and provides vital aid and services to millions of people across the Middle East. In Gaza, it has been the main supplier of food, water and shelter to civilians during the Israel-Hamas war.\n\nThe bill moving through parliament would brand the agency as a \"terror group,\" saying that the employees' alleged involvement in the Hamas assault shows that \"it is a terror organization that is no different from the Hamas terror organization.\" The bill also seeks to cut diplomatic ties between Israel and the agency.\n\nJuliette Touma, director of communications for UNRWA, said she wasn't entirely sure how the bill, if made law, would affect the agency, but said it would likely complicate its work. She said UNRWA is in contact with Israeli authorities on a daily basis, something the law would limit.\n\nThe European Union, Qatar and Saudi Arabia have all previously expressed concern about the bill, saying it would hobble the agency's work.", "source": {"uri": "winnipegfreepress.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Winnipeg Free Press"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": The agreement aims to establish a unified Palestinian government to rule Gaza after Israel's war on war concludes.\n\n\"Today we sign an agreement for national unity and we say that the path to completing this journey is national unity,\" said senior Hamas official Mousa Abu Marzouk at a news conference in Beijing.\n\nMustafa Barghouti, secretary-general of the Palestinian National Initiative, according to the Al-Jazeera report, stated that the \"Beijing Declaration,\" finalised after three days of intense talks, outlines a major techniques for Palestinian unity:\n\n1. Interim National Unity Government: An interim government will be formed, bringing together representatives from various factions, to govern post-war Gaza.\n\n2. Unified Palestinian Leadership: The agreement paves the way for the formation of a united Palestinian leadership, setting the stage for future elections.\n\n3. Free Election of a New Palestinian National Council: This pivotal step aims to establish a democratically elected body to represent Palestinian interests.\n\n4. Unified Resistance against Israeli Attacks: The factions have declared their commitment to united resistance against ongoing Israeli aggression.\n\n\"We're at a historic junction,\" Abu Marzouk said, according to CNN. \"Our people are rising up in their efforts to struggle.\"\n\nThe move towards unity comes at a crucial time, as the war in Gaza drags on and international pressure mounts for a ceasefire and a political solution to the Israel-Hamas war. The agreement, seen as a significant development, could potentially block Israeli attempts to manipulate internal Palestinian divisions.\n\nSpeaking to the media, Barghouti mentioned that 14 parties signed the unification agreement going \" much further\" than previous deals between the factions operating in the war-torn region.\n\nChina, which has played an active mediating role in the conflict, has welcomed the agreement and called for an \"international peace conference\" to end the war. Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi emphasised the importance of international support for the Palestinian reconciliation process, reiterating China's commitment to a two-state solution to the Israeli-Palestinian war. \"Reconciliation is an internal matter for the Palestinian factions, but at the same time, it cannot be achieved without the support of the international community,\" Wang was {"uri": "8239296483", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-23", "time": "11:19:24", "dateTime": "2024-07-23T11:19:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-23T11:18:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6117647290229797, "url": "https://www.ctvnews.ca/world/israel-hamas-war-netanyahu-signals-ceasefire-deal-could-be-shaping-up-as-deaths-top-39-000-1.6973902", "title": "Israel-Hamas war: Netanyahu signals ceasefire deal could be shaping up as deaths top 39,000", "body": "Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has signalled that a ceasefire deal that would free dozens of hostages from captivity in Gaza could be taking shape. Netanyahu is in Washington, where he was to meet with U.S. President Joe Biden and Vice President Kamala Harris.\n\nThe Israeli military ordered the evacuation of part of a crowded area in the Gaza Strip it had designated a humanitarian zone, while the Health Ministry in Gaza says over 39,000 Palestinians have now been killed in the nine-month war.\n\nEgypt, Qatar and the United States are pushing Israel and Hamas toward a phased deal that would stop the fighting and free the remaining hostages. Netanyahu's office has said a negotiating team will be sent to continue talks Thursday.\n\nIn China, Palestinian factions Hamas and Fatah signed a declaration on forming a unity government and ending a years-long rift. But previous declarations have failed, including a similar deal in 2011, casting doubt over whether the China-sponsored negotiations might actually lead to a resolution.\n\nHere's the latest:\n\nJERUSALEM -- Israeli forces raided a Palestinian city in the occupied West Bank, the military said Tuesday, killing what it said were two militants. The Palestinian Health Ministry said a woman was killed.\n\nThe military said a drone struck militants in the area of the northern West Bank city of Tulkarem overnight into Tuesday, killing Ashraf Nafa, who the military said was a local senior Hamas operative. It said another alleged militant, Mohammed Awad, was also killed in the raid, and said both had been behind attacks on Israeli soldiers. The Israeli military statement did not mention the woman killed.\n\nThere was no immediate claim from Hamas or other militant groups surrounding the men's affiliations.\n\nFor several years, the Israeli military has been carrying out near-nightly raids in the West Bank that intensified when the war in Gaza erupted. The Palestinian Health Ministry says more than 500 Palestinians have been killed in the ensuing violence, many of them in clashes with Israeli soldiers but others while throwing stones or protesting. People not involved in confrontations have also been killed.\n\nPalestinian attacks against Israelis have been on the rise in the territory.\n\nGENEVA -- A top World Health Organization official in Palestinian areas said Tuesday he's \"extremely worried\" about polio and other outbreaks of communicable diseases in Gaza after traces of the virus turned up in sewage samples in the territory.\n\nDr. Ayadil Saparbekov, team lead for health emergencies at WHO in the occupied Palestinian territory, said test results and a risk assessment were expected this week about how people and medical officials should respond to a possible outbreak.\n\nThere have been no confirmed human cases of polio in Gaza, but six of seven sewage samples tested positive for vaccine-derived polio virus, he said. That means that one or more people who got a polio vaccine jab have shed the virus in the environment.\n\n\"I am extremely worried about an outbreak happening in Gaza. And this is not only polio -- the different outbreaks of the communicable diseases that may happen,\" he told a United Nations briefing in Geneva by video, alluding to a hepatitis outbreak there in 2023.\n\nSaparbekov said lack of water, sanitation, and access to health care could lead to more people dying of communicable diseases than from injury-related conditions.\n\nRolando Gomez, a United Nations spokesperson in Geneva, said Israel \"as the occupying power\" has a responsibility \"to ensure assistance reaches those in need in Gaza\" and to \"create an enabling environment for the U.N. and our partners to operate.\"\n\nIsrael has announced plans to vaccinate its soldiers operating in Gaza against polio.\n\nRAMALLAH, West Bank -- Palestinian factions Hamas and Fatah signed a declaration in Beijing on ending a years-long rift, Chinese state broadcaster CCTV said Tuesday, taking a step toward potentially resolving the deep divide between the sides as the war in Gaza rages on.\n\nThe declaration by the two heavyweights of Palestinian politics -- and other smaller Palestinian groups -- to form a unity government for the Palestinian territories is the result of the latest in a series of talks meant to unite the sides.\n\nBut previous declarations have failed, including a similar deal in 2011, casting doubt over whether the China-sponsored negotiations might actually lead to a resolution. It also comes as Israel and Hamas are weighing an internationally backed ceasefire proposal that would wind down the nine-month war and free dozens of Israeli hostages held by Hamas.\n\nStill, the future of Gaza is undecided, with Israel vehemently opposed to any role by Hamas in governing Gaza. It has also rejected calls from the United States for the Fatah-dominated Palestinian Authority to run Gaza after the war ends. The lack of a post-war vision for running the Gaza Strip has complicated negotiations over a ceasefire.\n\nSince the current war broke out in Gaza almost 10 months ago, Hamas officials have said that the party does not want to return to ruling Gaza as it did before the conflict, and the group has called for formation of a government of technocrats to be agreed upon by the various Palestinian factions, which would prepare the way for elections for both Gaza and the West Bank, with the intention of forming a unified government.\n\nIsraeli soldiers move near the Israeli-Gaza border, as seen from southern Israel, Monday, July 8, 2024. (AP Photo/Leo Correa)\n\nTEL AVIV, Israel -- Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has signalled that a ceasefire deal that would free dozens of hostages from captivity in Gaza could be taking shape.\n\nIn a meeting late Monday in Washington with families of hostages, Netanyahu said the conditions to bring the captives back were \"ripening,\" according to a statement from his office. He said that was happening because of the fierce military pressure Israel was putting on Hamas.\n\nHe gave no further details on the deal's progress.\n\nFor weeks, Israel and Hamas have been weighing a United States-backed ceasefire deal that would bring a halt to the nine-month war and free the roughly 120 hostages taken by Hamas during its Oct. 7 attack. About a third of the hostages are said to be dead, and Israel's military announced Monday that two more died in captivity.\n\nNetanyahu faces intense pressure from a broad swath of Israelis to agree to the deal. He has vowed to defeat Hamas before stopping the war, a term that has been a main sticking point throughout the negotiations.\n\nThe families of hostages had demanded that Netanyahu nail down a deal before flying to Washington, where he will address Congress and is expected to meet President Joe Biden.\n\nJERUSALEM, Israel -- An Israeli parliamentary bill that seeks to label the main provider of aid for Palestinians in Gaza a terrorist group is moving ahead.\n\nLegislators voted 50-10 in favour of the bill in a preliminary vote in Israel's parliament Monday. The bill requires two more votes before becoming law.\n\nThe bill is the product of increasingly tense relations between Israel and the United Nations agency for Palestinian refugees, known as UNRWA. Israel has accused the agency of militant links, claiming that hundreds of its employees are members of militant groups, including some who allegedly participated in Hamas' Oct. 7 attacks on southern Israel. Those accusations led to a global cascade of funding cuts to the agency.\n\nUNRWA employs thousands of workers and provides vital aid and services to millions of people across the Middle East. In Gaza, it has been the main supplier of food, water and shelter to civilians during the Israel-Hamas war.\n\nThe bill moving through parliament would brand the agency as a \"terror group,\" saying that the employees' alleged involvement in the Hamas assault shows that \"it is a terror organization that is no different from the Hamas terror organization.\" The bill also seeks to cut diplomatic ties between Israel and the agency.\n\nJuliette Touma, director of communications for UNRWA, said she wasn't entirely sure how the bill, if made law, would affect the agency, but said it would likely complicate its work. She said UNRWA is in contact with Israeli authorities on a daily basis, something the law would limit.\n\nThe European Union, Qatar and Saudi Arabia have all previously expressed concern about the bill, saying it would hobble the agency's work.", "source": {"uri": "ctvnews.ca", "dataType": "news", "title": "CTV News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polio", He stressed that while reconciliation is an internal matter for Palestinians, international support is crucial for its success.\n\nWang Yi also reiterated China's call for a \"general, lasting, and viable ceasefire\" in Gaza, advocating for unhindered access to humanitarian aid.\n\n\"No excuse can justify the continued suffering and injury of civilians,\" he asserted, highlighting the urgent need for peace and stability in the region.\n\nChina's recent diplomatic endeavors have included facilitating rapprochement between regional rivals Iran and Saudi Arabia and hosting prior discussions between Hamas and Fatah in April. These moves are part of Beijing's broader strategy to influence peace and stability in the Middle East.\n\n\"China will continue to play a constructive role in promoting peace and stability in the Middle East,\" Wang Yi emphasized, highlighting Beijing's commitment to a diplomatic solution for Gaza's post-war governance and the broader Israeli war on besieged Palestinian regions.\n\nAccording to Gaza's Health Ministry, the war has resulted in over 39,000 deaths, predominantly civilians, although British journal The Lancet predicts the true number could be 186,00 accounting for all of those still missing under the rubble. The humanitarian situation remains dire, exacerbated by the rivalry between Hamas, which controls Gaza, and Fatah, which governs parts of the West Bank.\n\n\u00a9 Morocco World News. {"uri": "8239243094", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-23", "time": "10:47:06", "dateTime": "2024-07-23T10:47:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-23T10:46:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/hamas-ap-benjamin-netanyahu-gaza-israel-b2584346.html", "title": "Israel-Hamas war latest: Netanyahu signals cease-fire deal could be shaping up as deaths top 39,000", "body": "Our mission is to deliver unbiased, fact-based reporting that holds power to account and exposes the truth.\n\nWhether $5 or $50, every contribution counts.\n\nSupport us to deliver journalism without an agenda.\n\nIsraeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has signaled that a cease-fire deal that would free dozens of hostages from captivity in Gaza could be taking shape. Netanyahu is in Washington, where he was to meet with President Joe Biden and Vice President Kamala Harris.\n\nThe Israeli military ordered the evacuation of part of a crowded area in the Gaza Strip it had designated a humanitarian zone, while the Health Ministry in Gaza says over 39,000 Palestinians have now been killed in the nine-month war.\n\nEgypt, Qatar and the United States are pushing Israel and Hamas toward a phased deal that would stop the fighting and free the remaining hostages. Netanyahu's office has said a negotiating team will be sent to continue talks Thursday.\n\nIn China, Palestinian factions Hamas and Fatah signed a declaration on forming a unity government and ending a yearslong rift. But previous declarations have failed, including a similar deal in 2011, casting doubt over whether the China-sponsored negotiations might actually lead to a resolution.\n\nHere's the latest:\n\nIsraeli forces raid a Palestinian city in the West Bank, killing multiple people\n\nJERUSALEM -- Israeli forces raided a Palestinian city in the occupied West Bank, the military said Tuesday, killing what it said were two militants. The Palestinian Health Ministry said a woman was killed.\n\nThe military said a drone struck militants in the area of the northern West Bank city of Tulkarem overnight into Tuesday, killing Ashraf Nafa, who the military said was a local senior Hamas operative. It said another alleged militant, Mohammed Awad, was also killed in the raid, and said both had been behind attacks on Israeli soldiers. The Israeli military statement did not mention the woman killed.\n\nThere was no immediate claim from Hamas or other militant groups surrounding the men's affiliations.\n\nFor several years, the Israeli military has been carrying out near nightly raids in the West Bank that intensified when the war in Gaza erupted. The Palestinian Health Ministry says more than 500 Palestinians have been killed in the ensuing violence, many of them in clashes with Israeli soldiers but others while throwing stones or protesting. People not involved in confrontations have also been killed.\n\nPalestinian attacks against Israelis have been on the rise in the territory.\n\nA top WHO official is worried about possible polio and other disease outbreaks in Gaza\n\nGENEVA -- A top World Health Organization official in Palestinian areas said Tuesday he's \"extremely worried\" about polio and other outbreaks of communicable diseases in Gaza after traces of the virus turned up in sewage samples in the territory.\n\nDr. Ayadil Saparbekov, team lead for health emergencies at WHO in the occupied Palestinian territory, said test results and a risk assessment were expected this week about how people and medical officials should respond to a possible outbreak.\n\nThere have been no confirmed human cases of polio in Gaza, but six of seven sewage samples tested positive for vaccine-derived polio virus, he said. That means that one or more people who got a polio vaccine jab have shed the virus in the environment.\n\n\"I am extremely worried about an outbreak happening in Gaza. And this is not only polio -- the different outbreaks of the communicable diseases that may happen,\" he told a United Nations briefing in Geneva by video, alluding to a hepatitis outbreak there in 2023.\n\nSaparbekov said lack of water, sanitation, and access to health care could lead to more people dying of communicable diseases than from injury related conditions.\n\nRolando Gomez, a United Nations spokesperson in Geneva, said Israel \"as the occupying power\" has a responsibility \"to ensure assistance reaches those in need in Gaza\" and to \"create an enabling environment for the U.N. and our partners to operate.\"\n\nIsrael has announced plans to vaccinate its soldiers operating in Gaza against polio.\n\nPalestinian factions sign a declaration in the latest attempt to clear the way for a unity government as the war in Gaza rages on\n\nRAMALLAH, West Bank -- Palestinian factions Hamas and Fatah signed a declaration in Beijing on ending a yearslong rift, Chinese state state broadcaster CCTV said Tuesday, taking a step toward potentially resolving the deep divide between the sides as the war in Gaza rages on.\n\nThe declaration by the two heavyweights of Palestinian politics -- and other smaller Palestinian groups -- to form a unity government for the Palestinian territories is the result of the latest in a series of talks meant to unite the sides.\n\nBut previous declarations have failed, including a similar deal in 2011, casting doubt over whether the China-sponsored negotiations might actually lead to a resolution. It also comes as Israel and Hamas are weighing an internationally backed cease-fire proposal that would wind down the nine-month war and free dozens of Israeli hostages held by Hamas.\n\nStill, the future of Gaza is undecided, with Israel vehemently opposed to any role by Hamas in governing Gaza. It has also rejected calls from the United States for the Fatah-dominated Palestinian Authority to run Gaza after the war ends. The lack of a postwar vision for running the Gaza Strip has complicated negotiations over a cease-fire.\n\nSince the current war broke out in Gaza almost 10 months ago, Hamas officials have said that the party does not want to return to ruling Gaza as it did before the conflict, and the group has called for formation of a government of technocrats to be agreed upon by the various Palestinian factions, which would prepare the way for elections for both Gaza and the West Bank, with the intention of forming a unified government.\n\nConditions for a cease-fire deal that would release hostages from captivity in Gaza are 'ripening,' Israel's Netanyahu says\n\nTEL AVIV, Israel -- Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has signaled that a cease-fire deal that would free dozens of hostages from captivity in Gaza could be taking shape.\n\nIn a meeting late Monday in Washington with families of hostages, Netanyahu said the conditions to bring the captives back were \"ripening,\" according to a statement from his office. He said that was happening because of the fierce military pressure Israel was putting on Hamas.\n\nHe gave no further details on the deal's progress.\n\nFor weeks, Israel and Hamas have been weighing a United States-backed cease-fire deal that would bring a halt to the nine-month war and free the roughly 120 hostages taken by Hamas during its Oct. 7 attack. About a third of the hostages are said to be dead, and Israel's military announced Monday that two more died in captivity.\n\nNetanyahu faces intense pressure from a broad swath of Israelis to agree to the deal. He has vowed to defeat Hamas before stopping the war, a term that has been a main sticking point throughout the negotiations.\n\nThe families of hostages had demanded that Netanyahu nail down a deal before flying to Washington, where he will address Congress and is expected to meet President Joe Biden.\n\nBill labeling UN Palestinian aid agency as a 'terror group' moves forward in Israel's parliament\n\nJERUSALEM, Israel -- An Israeli parliamentary bill that seeks to label the main provider of aid for Palestinians in Gaza a terrorist group is moving ahead.\n\nLegislators voted 50-10 in favor of the bill in a preliminary vote in Israel's parliament Monday. The bill requires two more votes before becoming law.\n\nThe bill is the product of increasingly tense relations between Israel and the United Nations agency for Palestinian refugees, known as UNRWA. Israel has accused the agency of militant links, claiming that hundreds of its employees are members of militant groups, including some who allegedly participated in Hamas' Oct. 7 attacks on southern Israel. Those accusations led to a global cascade of funding cuts to the agency.\n\nUNRWA employs thousands of workers and provides vital aid and services to millions of people across the Middle East. In Gaza, it has been the main supplier of food, water and shelter to civilians during the Israel-Hamas war.\n\nThe bill moving through parliament would brand the agency as a \"terror group,\" saying that the employees' alleged involvement in the Hamas assault shows that \"it is a terror organization that is no different from the Hamas terror organization.\" The bill also seeks to cut diplomatic ties between Israel and the agency.\n\nJuliette Touma, director of communications for UNRWA, said she wasn't entirely sure how the bill, if made law, would affect the agency, but said it would likely complicate its work. She said UNRWA is in contact with Israeli authorities on a daily basis, something the law would limit.\n\nThe European Union, Qatar and Saudi Arabia have all previously expressed concern about the {"uri": "8239234248", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-23", "time": "10:41:30", "dateTime": "2024-07-23T10:41:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-23T10:40:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://www.winnipegfreepress.com/world/2024/07/23/israel-hamas-war-latest-netanyahu-signals-cease-fire-deal-could-be-shaping-up-as-deaths-top-39000", "title": "Israel-Hamas war latest: Netanyahu signals cease-fire deal could be shaping up as deaths top 39,000", "body": "I agree to the Terms and Conditions, Cookie and Privacy Policies, and CASL agreement.\n\nIsraeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has signaled that a cease-fire deal that would free dozens of hostages from captivity in Gaza could be taking shape. Netanyahu is in Washington, where he was to meet with President Joe Biden and Vice President Kamala Harris.\n\nThe Israeli military ordered the evacuation of part of a crowded area in the Gaza Strip it had designated a humanitarian zone, while the Health Ministry in Gaza says over 39,000 Palestinians have now been killed in the nine-month war.\n\nEgypt, Qatar and the United States are pushing Israel and Hamas toward a phased deal that would stop the fighting and free the remaining hostages. Netanyahu's office has said a negotiating team will be sent to continue talks Thursday.\n\nIn China, Palestinian factions Hamas and Fatah signed a declaration on forming a unity government and ending a yearslong rift. But previous declarations have failed, including a similar deal in 2011, casting doubt over whether the China-sponsored negotiations might actually lead to a resolution.\n\nHere's the latest:\n\nIsraeli forces raid a Palestinian city in the West Bank, killing multiple people\n\nJERUSALEM -- Israeli forces raided a Palestinian city in the occupied West Bank, the military said Tuesday, killing what it said were two militants. The Palestinian Health Ministry said a woman was killed.\n\nThe military said a drone struck militants in the area of the northern West Bank city of Tulkarem overnight into Tuesday, killing Ashraf Nafa, who the military said was a local senior Hamas operative. It said another alleged militant, Mohammed Awad, was also killed in the raid, and said both had been behind attacks on Israeli soldiers. The Israeli military statement did not mention the woman killed.\n\nThere was no immediate claim from Hamas or other militant groups surrounding the men's affiliations.\n\nFor several years, the Israeli military has been carrying out near nightly raids in the West Bank that intensified when the war in Gaza erupted. The Palestinian Health Ministry says more than 500 Palestinians have been killed in the ensuing violence, many of them in clashes with Israeli soldiers but others while throwing stones or protesting. People not involved in confrontations have also been killed.\n\nPalestinian attacks against Israelis have been on the rise in the territory.\n\nA top WHO official is worried about possible polio and other disease outbreaks in Gaza\n\nGENEVA -- A top World Health Organization official in Palestinian areas said Tuesday he's \"extremely worried\" about polio and other outbreaks of communicable diseases in Gaza after traces of the virus turned up in sewage samples in the territory.\n\nDr. Ayadil Saparbekov, team lead for health emergencies at WHO in the occupied Palestinian territory, said test results and a risk assessment were expected this week about how people and medical officials should respond to a possible outbreak.\n\nThere have been no confirmed human cases of polio in Gaza, but six of seven sewage samples tested positive for vaccine-derived polio virus, he said. That means that one or more people who got a polio vaccine jab have shed the virus in the environment.\n\n\"I am extremely worried about an outbreak happening in Gaza. And this is not only polio -- the different outbreaks of the communicable diseases that may happen,\" he told a United Nations briefing in Geneva by video, alluding to a hepatitis outbreak there in 2023.\n\nSaparbekov said lack of water, sanitation, and access to health care could lead to more people dying of communicable diseases than from injury related conditions.\n\nRolando Gomez, a United Nations spokesperson in Geneva, said Israel \"as the occupying power\" has a responsibility \"to ensure assistance reaches those in need in Gaza\" and to \"create an enabling environment for the U.N. and our partners to operate.\"\n\nIsrael has announced plans to vaccinate its soldiers operating in Gaza against polio.\n\nPalestinian factions sign a declaration in the latest attempt to clear the way for a unity government as the war in Gaza rages on\n\nRAMALLAH, West Bank -- Palestinian factions Hamas and Fatah signed a declaration in Beijing on ending a yearslong rift, Chinese state state broadcaster CCTV said Tuesday, taking a step toward potentially resolving the deep divide between the sides as the war in Gaza rages on.\n\nThe declaration by the two heavyweights of Palestinian politics -- and other smaller Palestinian groups -- to form a unity government for the Palestinian territories is the result of the latest in a series of talks meant to unite the sides.\n\nBut previous declarations have failed, including a similar deal in 2011, casting doubt over whether the China-sponsored negotiations might actually lead to a resolution. It also comes as Israel and Hamas are weighing an internationally backed cease-fire proposal that would wind down the nine-month war and free dozens of Israeli hostages held by Hamas.\n\nStill, the future of Gaza is undecided, with Israel vehemently opposed to any role by Hamas in governing Gaza. It has also rejected calls from the United States for the Fatah-dominated Palestinian Authority to run Gaza after the war ends. The lack of a postwar vision for running the Gaza Strip has complicated negotiations over a cease-fire.\n\nSince the current war broke out in Gaza almost 10 months ago, Hamas officials have said that the party does not want to return to ruling Gaza as it did before the conflict, and the group has called for formation of a government of technocrats to be agreed upon by the various Palestinian factions, which would prepare the way for elections for both Gaza and the West Bank, with the intention of forming a unified government.\n\nConditions for a cease-fire deal that would release hostages from captivity in Gaza are 'ripening,' Israel's Netanyahu says\n\nTEL AVIV, Israel -- Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has signaled that a cease-fire deal that would free dozens of hostages from captivity in Gaza could be taking shape.\n\nIn a meeting late Monday in Washington with families of hostages, Netanyahu said the conditions to bring the captives back were \"ripening,\" according to a statement from his office. He said that was happening because of the fierce military pressure Israel was putting on Hamas.\n\nHe gave no further details on the deal's progress.\n\nFor weeks, Israel and Hamas have been weighing a United States-backed cease-fire deal that would bring a halt to the nine-month war and free the roughly 120 hostages taken by Hamas during its Oct. 7 attack. About a third of the hostages are said to be dead, and Israel's military announced Monday that two more died in captivity.\n\nNetanyahu faces intense pressure from a broad swath of Israelis to agree to the deal. He has vowed to defeat Hamas before stopping the war, a term that has been a main sticking point throughout the negotiations.\n\nThe families of hostages had demanded that Netanyahu nail down a deal before flying to Washington, where he will address Congress and is expected to meet President Joe Biden.\n\nBill labeling UN Palestinian aid agency as a 'terror group' moves forward in Israel's parliament\n\nJERUSALEM, Israel -- An Israeli parliamentary bill that seeks to label the main provider of aid for Palestinians in Gaza a terrorist group is moving ahead.\n\nLegislators voted 50-10 in favor of the bill in a preliminary vote in Israel's parliament Monday. The bill requires two more votes before becoming law.\n\nThe bill is the product of increasingly tense relations between Israel and the United Nations agency for Palestinian refugees, known as UNRWA. Israel has accused the agency of militant links, claiming that hundreds of its employees are members of militant groups, including some who allegedly participated in Hamas' Oct. 7 attacks on southern Israel. Those accusations led to a global cascade of funding cuts to the agency.\n\nUNRWA employs thousands of workers and provides vital aid and services to millions of people across the Middle East. In Gaza, it has been the main supplier of food, water and shelter to civilians during the Israel-Hamas war.\n\nThe bill moving through parliament would brand the agency as a \"terror group,\" saying that the employees' alleged involvement in the Hamas assault shows that \"it is a terror organization that is no different from the Hamas terror organization.\" The bill also seeks to cut diplomatic ties between Israel and the agency.\n\nJuliette Touma, director of communications for UNRWA, said she wasn't entirely sure how the bill, if made law, would affect the agency, but said it would likely complicate its work. She said UNRWA is in contact with Israeli authorities on a daily basis, something the law would limit.\n\nThe European Union, Qatar and Saudi Arabia have all previously expressed concern about the {"uri": "8239461020", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-23", "time": "13:02:15", "dateTime": "2024-07-23T13:02:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-23T13:01:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://www.chinadailyasia.com/hk/article/588803", "title": "Wang: PLO sole legitimate representative of Palestinian people", "body": "BEIJING - The core outcome of the reconciliation dialogue among Palestinian factions held in Beijing is to specify that the Palestine Liberation Organization is the sole legitimate representative of all the Palestinian people, Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi said on Tuesday.\n\nWang, also a member of the Political Bureau of the Communist Party of China Central Committee, made the remarks at the closing ceremony of the reconciliation dialogue among Palestinian factions.\n\nHe also witnessed the signing of a declaration on ending division and strengthening unity by 14 Palestinian factions.\n\nThe most important consensus reached at this dialogue is to achieve grand reconciliation and unity among the 14 factions, and the core outcome is to make clear that the PLO is the sole legitimate representative of all the Palestinian people, said the top Chinese diplomat.\n\nREAD MORE: Palestinian factions sign unity declaration in Beijing\n\nThe most significant highlight is the agreement to form an interim national reconciliation government focused on the post-war governance of Gaza, and the strongest call is for the creation of a truly independent Palestinian state in accordance with relevant United Nations resolutions, he said.\n\n\"The key to the internal reconciliation process of the Palestinian factions is to maintain firm confidence, grasp the direction and proceed step by step.\"\n\nReconciliation is an internal affair of all Palestinian factions, and cannot be achieved without the support of the international community. On the road to promoting reconciliation, China shares the same direction and goals as the vast majority of Arab and Islamic countries, he said.\n\nNoting that the Palestinian issue is at the core of the Middle East issue, he said China harbors no self-interest concerning the Palestinian issue, was one of the first countries to recognize the PLO and the State of Palestine, and has always firmly supported the Palestinian people in restoring their legitimate national rights.\n\nALSO READ: China backs Palestinian factions' reconciliation through talks\n\nThe conflict in Gaza continues to drag on, and its spillover impact is spreading, he said. \"To get out of the current conflict predicament, China proposes a three-step approach.\"\n\nThe first step is to promote a comprehensive, lasting and sustainable ceasefire in the Gaza Strip as soon as possible and ensure humanitarian assistance and relief access, he said, adding that the international community should further unite on the issue of ceasefire.\n\nThe second step is to uphold the principle of \"the Palestinians governing Palestine\" and work together to promote post-war governance in Gaza, said Wang.\n\nGaza is an inseparable and important part of Palestine, and starting post-war reconstruction as soon as possible has become an urgent issue in the next stage. The international community should support Palestinian factions to form an interim government with national consensus to effectively manage Gaza and the West Bank, he said.\n\nREAD MORE: UN experts: Recognize Palestinian state\n\nThe third step is to promote Palestine to become a full member of the United Nations and begin to implement the two-state solution. A more significant, more authoritative and more effective international peace conference should be supported, and a timetable and road map for this should be made, he said.\n\nHe said ceasefire and humanitarian relief are top priorities, \"the Palestinians governing Palestine\" is the basic principle of post-war reconstruction in Gaza, and the two-state solution is the fundamental way out for the future.\n\n\"The international community should support the parties concerned in implementing the three-step approach with a serious attitude.\"", "source": {"uri": "chinadailyasia.com", {"uri": "8233809887", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "16:00:53", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T16:00:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T16:00:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6000000238418579, "url": "https://www.newarab.com/news/are-fatah-hamas-reconciliation-talks-beijing-waste-time", "title": "Are Fatah-Hamas reconciliation talks in Beijing a waste of time?", "body": "China has been hosting Fatah-Hamas talks with the aim of achieving reconciliation between the bitterly divided Palestinian factions [Getty]\n\nThe latest round of Fatah-Hamas reconciliation talks are due to take place in Beijing on 20-21 July, triggered in part by China's continuing push for dialogue between the factions as a means to end longstanding internal Palestinian divisions - which it sees as key to securing an ultimate resolution to the Palestinian issue.\n\nAhmed Majdalani, a senior member of the Palestine Liberation Organisation's (PLO) Executive Committee, said to Al-Araby Al-Jadeed, The New Arab's Arabic-language sister edition, that a two-way discussion would be held between Fatah and Hamas on 20 July. This would be followed on 21 July with a meeting for all the factions to resume the intra-Palestinian dialogue around reconciliation.\n\nAzzam al-Ahmad, a member of the PLO's Executive Committee as well as Fatah's Central Committee, said to Anadolu Agency that his movement would \"take part in the China meeting with an open mind and is serious about reaching an end to the division\".\n\nFor his part, senior Hamas official Husam Badran said to Anadolu Agency that Hamas was approaching China's invitation \"with a positive spirit and patriotic responsibility\" as the movement was \"eager to achieve national unity\".\n\nLin Jian, a spokesperson at China's Ministry of Foreign Affairs, said in a press briefing last week that China would work with all parties in Palestine to strengthen reconciliation efforts.\n\nHe asserted that Beijing had always supported the Palestinian factions in achieving reconciliation and solidarity through dialogue and consultation, and stood ready to provide platforms and opportunities to all the Palestinian factions to carry out dialogue with the aim of reconciliation.\n\nThe most recent round of China-sponsored Fatah-Hamas talks took place in Beijing in April, but yielded no practical solutions around ending the bitter divide which has continued for around 17 years.\n\nLikewise, Arab states have made efforts to promote a rapprochement, none of which have succeeded in bringing the divergent perspectives of the two sides together or advancing an end to the crisis.\n\nChina's efforts spring from its belief that the key to the solution to the most pressing issue today in the Middle East in the wake of the Gaza war \"is achieving internal unity as a first step to paving the way towards building an independent state on the 1967 borders with East Jerusalem as its capital,\" said Lin Wei, a researcher at the Jiangxi Institute of Political Studies in China.\n\nHe said Beijing realizes that continuing Palestinian division has become a cover for the continuation of the Israeli killing machine in Gaza.\n\n\"Despite the depth of the divide, China is acting as a responsible state and is banking on its capability to influence the relevant parties, as it enjoys strong relations with all Palestinian factions, including Hamas and Fatah\", he said.\n\nHe also pointed out that China \"knows well it won't be easy to reap the fruits of these efforts through just one or two sessions, due to the differing approaches every side takes with regards to resolving the Palestinian issue\", in reference to the peace process versus armed resistance.\n\nBut Li Yang, a professor at Tseung Kwan Institute of Studies and Research (based in Hong Kong), believes Beijing's decision to host a new round of talks, despite the failure of all previous rounds over a decade and a half, is futile and doomed to failure.\n\nHe says there is no doubt Beijing has its own aims - linked to promoting its image on the world stage as a sponsor of peace, after failing to achieve any breakthrough in the Ukrainian crisis.\n\nYang pointed out that China had intensified its efforts regarding Palestinian reconciliation and started up the Fatah-Hamas talks after its successful mediation between Tehran and Riyadh in March 2023.\n\nHe thinks this is because it hopes to secure more breakthroughs and play a greater role in solving the crises of the Middle East in a way that will serve its strategic interests in the region.\n\nHowever, he believes China's approach to the Palestinian issue and Fatah-Hamas reconciliation is marred by many weaknesses that prevent it from being able to replicate its experience in the Saudi-Iranian issue.\n\nIn his view, the biggest obstacle is ignoring the pivotal role of the US in this issue, due to the direct and powerful influence it wields over all parties to the conflict, including Israel and the Palestinian Authority itself, led by Fatah.", "source": {"uri": "newarab.com", "dataType": "news", National unity is our goal and we urge its realization,\" said Abu Marzuk following the discussions with Wang and other delegates.", "source": {"uri": "pakobserver.net", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8235795384", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-21", "time": "06:14:52", "dateTime": "2024-07-21T06:14:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-21T06:05:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6000000238418579, "url": "https://exbulletin.com/politics/2797183/", "title": "China boosts Middle East diplomatic ambitions with talks between Hamas and rival Fatah - ExBulletin", "body": "China has never hidden this goal. In May, Chinese leader Xi Jinping told a meeting of Chinese and Arab diplomats in Beijing that the war should not continue indefinitely. Xi reiterated Beijing's support for a broad-based, authoritative and effective international peace conference, as well as China's call for the establishment of an independent Palestinian state.\n\nChina is also expected to seek a role in the post-war Gaza Strip to help rebuild infrastructure. Diplomats including Cao Xiaolin, China's ambassador to Qatar, and envoy Wang Kejian met with Hamas political leader Ismail Haniyeh in March.\n\nHamas issued a statement saying Chinese officials had told Haniyeh that Hamas was part of the Palestinian national fabric and that China wanted to maintain relations with it.\n\nIt is a delicate balance for China because it also maintains diplomatic and trade relations with Israel, even though Beijing has never officially condemned the October 7 attacks.\n\nChina does not offer itself as a mediator between anyone, Mehdawi said. China cannot call for a peace conference while the Palestinians themselves are not repairing their home.\n\nChina could act as a guarantor for a Palestinian unity deal, having joined Oman and Iraq in brokering a deal last year between Saudi Arabia and Iran that restored diplomatic ties between the two rivals. The United States and Europe were not involved in that process.\n\nChina wants to be part of any major diplomatic gathering that ends this conflict, and it would like to play a significant role in it, said Jon Alterman, senior vice president and director of the Middle East program at the Center for Strategic and International Studies.\n\nOverall, China sees this as a relatively inexpensive way to do something, he said. If it works, it's prestigious, and if it doesn't, it's not a bad thing, not a fault.\n\nPalestinian unity is elusive. Power struggles have long divided Fatah and Hamas, a rift that deepened in 2007 with Hamas's chaotic takeover of the Gaza Strip after elections the previous year. That rift has since led the Fatah-dominated Palestinian Authority to govern only parts of the West Bank, while Palestinians complain of diminishing legitimacy, according to a 2023 study by the Palestinian Center for Policy and Survey Research, an independent think tank based in Ramallah. Israel has exercised its power over the West Bank and Gaza in different ways.\n\nThe Beijing talks will be held at the Diaoyutai State Guest House, a sprawling complex of gardens, lakes, buildings and a hotel where the Communist Party hosts foreign dignitaries. It will bring together a delegation of senior Fatah officials, including its vice chairman, Mahmoud Aloul, with their Hamas counterparts led by Haniyeh.\n\nChinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi will meet with both sides, a Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesperson said when confirming the meetings. The two factions will also meet without Wang, who is China's top diplomat, but he is expected to join the two sides on the last day, according to Palestinian officials familiar with the schedule.\n\nChina's advance acknowledgement of the talks suggests a different level of confidence in the results they could deliver. A first round of meetings was held in April, with little progress, and China only announced the talks after participants had left the country. The Beijing talks followed a similar meeting in Moscow in February.\n\nWhen it came time for Chinese officials to host the second round of unity talks scheduled here on June 24, Hamas and Fatah pulled out at the last minute. Both factions issued statements accusing the other of rejecting the meeting and expressing gratitude to their Chinese hosts.\n\nThe historical divide between Hamas and Fatah is deep, said Maria Papageorgiou, professor of politics and international relations at the University of Exeter, but China's direct influence on Palestinian politics remains limited compared to other actors.\n\nChina's relations with the Palestinians date back to the 1960s, when the government of Communist Party Chairman Mao Zedong provided food, weapons, training and support to the Palestine Liberation Organization (PLO).\n\nIn 1988, China was one of the first countries in the world to recognize a Palestinian state, and its representative office in Beijing was upgraded to an embassy in 1974. Today, the Palestinians rely primarily on China for diplomatic support at the United Nations, officials say.\n\nThese ties to the PLO have long been closely tied to China's advance in the Middle East, driven primarily by economic interests that have also expanded its foreign policy influence. Much of Beijing's crude oil imports come from the region, and Chinese investment has funded billions of dollars in infrastructure projects including ports, highways and skyscrapers.\n\nAlthough China has acquired a significant economic presence in the Middle East, its [diplomatic] Credibility does not always correspond to influence, Papageorgiou said, adding that China's now strained relations with Israel over the conflict will make it difficult to facilitate conversations between Palestinians and Israelis without U.S. involvement.\n\nIn a statement to NBC News, the Chinese Foreign Ministry said China has always firmly supported the just cause of the Palestinian people. Without naming the United States, it added that China calls on major influential countries to remove their tinted glass and abandon double standards when dealing with regional affairs.\n\nAccording to Alterman, the Chinese worldview is not based on a strong international community that defends common interests. China prefers to engage one at a time, so to the extent that it undermines this broader effort to encourage multilateralism, I think the United States sees it as pointless.\n\nPalestinian Ambassador Mehdawi does not see China competing to replace the United States as the dominant power in the region in terms of diplomacy. Rather, he sees China's involvement in the unity negotiations as fulfilling a role that the United States is unable to assume because of its support for Israel.\n\nChinese foreign policy is not that ambitious, he said. The Chinese know their limits. The failures of the United States suggest that China is doing more.", "source": {"uri": "exbulletin.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "ExBulletin"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8239283866", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-23", "time": "11:12:10", "dateTime": "2024-07-23T11:12:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-23T11:11:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5960784554481506, "url": "https://www.chinadaily.com.cn/a/202407/23/WS669f8dafa31095c51c50f813.html", "title": "China acting responsibly in hosting reconciliation talks: China Daily editorial", "body": "As Israel's military operations in Gaza, most recently the town of Rafah, intensify global humanitarian concerns over civilian casualties, the issue of Palestinian statehood is back in the spotlight.\n\nWith more and more countries supporting the \"two-state\" solution to the historical conflict between Israel and Palestine, the internal divide among the Palestinians has emerged as an outstanding obstacle on the road to Palestinian statehood. The Palestinians' seeming inability to manage internal divisions and control the frictions has been a regular pretext for Western and Israeli opposition to immediate statehood for the Palestinians.\n\nBy hosting a fresh round of interfactional talks among Palestine's major political actors, Beijing is taking a proactive step to push for Palestinian national reconciliation, and ultimately Palestinian statehood. The talks also represent a new attempt by Palestine to introduce order at home.\n\nAs Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesperson Mao Ning stated, the Chinese side has persistently shown solid support for the factions in Palestine to achieve reconciliation and unity through consultation and to build an independent state as soon as possible. The latest Beijing talks are a part of those efforts.\n\nThe second round of reconciliation negotiations going on in Beijing reportedly feature 14 Palestinian political factions, including the Palestinian National Liberation Movement (Fatah) and the Palestinian Islamic Resistance Movement (Hamas). While the meeting is an endorsement of Chinese enthusiasm for the Palestinians' pursuit of statehood, a more important driver behind it is the Palestinian recognition that reconciliation is necessary for a stable state. A Fatah official was quoted by a Turkish news agency as saying his organization would \"participate in the meeting in Beijing with an open mind, and seriously consider ending division\". It also quoted a member of the Hamas Political Bureau as saying they would accept Beijing's invitation, because they \"yearn to accomplish national unity\". Representatives of the two factions held their first consultation in Beijing in April, which was widely viewed as a promising start for the journey toward reconciliation among the various Palestinian factions.\n\nWhat Beijing has contributed to that process has not been limited to moral support. According to the Foreign Ministry, Beijing's position has been fully reflected in the advisory opinions issued by the International Court of Justice calling for Israel to immediately end its illegal occupation of Palestinian land.\n\nIf, as some international observers have reported, China could offer a framework for the talks to be productive, that would certainly be a greater contribution.\n\nSince Palestinian divisions suit the agendas of Israel and the United States, Tel Aviv and Washington have been trying to distort Beijing's good intentions and undermine and obstruct its efforts to promote Palestinian reconciliation. Doing so leaves them at odds with the conscience of the world. China stands firmly on the side of peace and justice and it will continue to do what it can to promote the settlement of the Palestinian issue.", "source": {"uri": "chinadaily.com.cn", "dataType": {"uri": "8234755132", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-20", "time": "09:15:59", "dateTime": "2024-07-20T09:15:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-20T09:15:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "http://www.ruthfullyyours.com/2024/07/20/palestinian-leaders-prefer-murderers-and-rapists-over-reforms-by-bassam-tawil/", "title": "Palestinian Leaders Prefer Murderers and Rapists Over Reforms by Bassam Tawil", "body": "The PA has always stated that it prefers a one-state solution: a state of Palestine replacing all of Israel.\n\nThe Biden administration's plan to \"revitalize\" the Palestinian Authority (PA) is being interpreted by Palestinian leaders as permission to form an alliance with the murderers and rapists of the Iran-backed terrorist group Hamas.\n\nIn November 2023, the Biden administration called for \"revitalizing\" the PA in the hopes that it would be able to oversee the Gaza Strip once the Israel-Hamas war ends.\n\nUS State Department spokesperson Matthew Miller said that the US looks forward to working with the new PA government headed by Mohammed Mustafa, which was established last April, \"to deliver on credible reforms.\"\n\n\"A revitalized PA is essential to delivering results for the Palestinian people in both the West Bank and Gaza and establishing the conditions for stability in the broader region,\" Miller said.\n\nAccording to Yohanan Tzoreff, a senior research fellow at the Institute for National Security Studies:\n\n\"President Biden coined the term 'revitalized Palestinian Authority' as a linchpin of a two-state vision, which he continues to view as the exclusive solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict...\n\n\"The PA, under Abbas, has faced substantial challenges, including a loss of trust among its people and governmental ineptitude manifested by constant decline in provided services. Abbas, himself, is increasingly perceived as an autocrat determined to reject vital reforms, and the authority of the courts has diminished, with their rulings constrained by the Chairman's decrees, sparking growing unrest among lawyers' groups and trade unions...\n\n\"Mahmoud Abbas and his fellow PA leaders refrained from condemning the massacres carried out by Hamas on October 7. Some even justified the acts. The PA also continues to pay monthly allowances to the families of Palestinians who perpetrated attacks against Israelis, a move perceived in Israel as encouraging terrorism.\"\n\nInstead of starting a \"reform process\" within the PA, as the Biden administration has demanded, Abbas and his top officials are still pursuing unity and reconciliation with Hamas, whose members carried out the October 7 atrocities against thousands of Israelis. It is hard to see how such an alliance between the two Palestinian parties would even begin to benefit the Palestinians or advance peace and security in the Middle East.\n\nPalestinians living under the rule of the PA and Hamas have long been complaining about financial and administrative corruption, as well as repression and human rights violations. Here is what Human Rights Watch had to say about the status of human rights under the PA and Hamas:\n\n\"Both the Fatah-dominated Palestinian Authority (PA) in the West Bank and the Islamic Resistance Movement (Hamas) in Gaza have in recent years carried out scores of arbitrary arrests for peaceful criticism of the authorities, particularly on social media, among independent journalists, on university campuses, and at demonstrations. As the Fatah-Hamas feud deepened despite attempts at reconciliation, PA security services have targeted supporters of Hamas and vice versa. Relying primarily on overly broad laws that criminalize activity such as causing 'sectarian strife' or insulting 'higher authorities,' the PA and Hamas use detention to punish critics and deter them and others from further activism. In detention, security forces routinely taunt, threaten, beat, and force detainees into painful stress positions for hours at a time.\"\n\nSince October 7, Abbas's ruling Fatah faction and Hamas have been holding talks to discuss ways of achieving unity and reconciliation. Most of the negotiations have been taking place in China, which appears to be vying for a bigger role in the Middle East.\n\nThe Biden administration has so far refrained from demanding that the PA halt its efforts to form a partnership with Hamas, which is designated by the US as a foreign terrorist group.\n\nThe Biden administration should instead be encouraging Palestinians to get rid of Hamas rather than seeking unity and reconciliation with a terrorist group responsible for the worst massacre of Jews since the Holocaust.\n\nIn mid-July, China again invited Fatah and Hamas officials to pursue the unity and reconciliation talks in Beijing. Fatah and Hamas representatives welcomed the Chinese invitation.\n\nSenior Hamas official Hussam Badran stated that his group \"dealt with this invitation in a positive spirit and with national responsibility in order to achieve national unity.\"\n\nThe Hamas delegation will be headed by Ismail Haniyeh, while the Fatah team will be headed by Mahmoud al-Aloul, Deputy Chairman of Fatah.\n\nIn a statement carried by the PA's official news agency Wafa, Fatah renewed its \"great appreciation for China, which hosted the national dialogue between Fatah and Hamas, and its desire to ensure the success of the Chinese efforts.\"\n\nAzzam al-Ahmad, a member of the Executive Committee of the Palestine Liberation Organization and the Fatah Central Committee, told the Turkish Anadolu Agency that his faction \"will participate in the China meeting, and is serious about ending the dispute [with Hamas].\"\n\nAnother Fatah official, Abdel Fattah Dawla, said:\n\n\"We in Fatah are open to resolving and removing all obstacles in the way of reconciliation in light of the difficult circumstances that the Palestinian cause is going through.\"\n\nOn the eve of the resumption of the Fatah-Hamas unity talks, Jibril Rajoub, secretary-general of Fatah, justified Hamas's October 7 attack during which 1,200 Israelis were murdered, raped, tortured and burned alive, and more than 240 others were kidnapped to the Gaza Strip.\n\nRajoub, who previously served as head of the PA's Preventive Security Force in the West Bank, described the atrocities as a \"defensive operation.\" He boasted that the October 7 attack had \"thwarted attempts to liquidate the Palestinian issue, as well as efforts to achieve normalization [between Israel and Saudi Arabia].\"\n\nHamas and its patrons in Iran have previously stated that one of the goals of the October 7 massacre was to thwart US efforts to achieve normalization between Israel and Saudi Arabia.\n\nSuch statements show why there is basically no difference between the PA and Hamas. Both organizations believe that murdering Jews helps the Palestinians and advances their objective of preventing Israel and the Arab states from normalizing relations with each other.\n\nThe PA is lying when it states that it supports a two-state solution. How can the PA advocate for a two-state solution while its leaders are praising the October 7 atrocities and working to form an alliance with Hamas, an Islamist terrorist group whose charter openly
